books.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns

chapters.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:1
verses.text: On the Councils, or, The Faith of the Easterns.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:2
verses.text: To the most dearly loved and blessed brethren our fellow-bishops of the province of Germania Prima and Germania Secunda, Belgica Prima and Belgica Secunda, Lugdunensis Prima and Lugdunensis Secunda, and the province of Aquitania, and the province of Novempopulana, and to the laity and clergy of Tolosa in the Provincia Narbonensis, and to the bishops of the provinces of Britain, Hilary the servant of Christ, eternal salvation in God our Lord.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:3
verses.text: I had determined, beloved brethren, to send no letter to you concerning the affairs of the Church in consequence of your prolonged silence.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:4
verses.text: For when I had by writing from several cities of the Roman world frequently informed you of the faith and efforts of our religious brethren, the bishops of the East, and how the Evil One profiting by the discords of the times had with envenomed lips and tongue hissed out his deadly doctrine, I was afraid.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:5
verses.text: I feared lest while so many bishops were involved in the serious danger of disastrous sin or disastrous mistake, you were holding your peace because a defiled and sin-stained conscience tempted you to despair.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:6
verses.text: Ignorance I could not attribute to you; you had been too often warned.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:7
verses.text: I judged therefore that I also ought to observe silence towards you, carefully remembering the Lord's saying, that those who after a first and second entreaty, and in spite of the witness of the Church, neglect to hear, are to be unto us as heathen men and publicans.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:8
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:9
verses.text: But when I received the letters that your blessed faith inspired, and understood that their slow arrival and their paucity were due to the remoteness and secrecy of my place of exile, I rejoiced in the Lord that you had continued pure and undefiled by the contagion of any execrable heresy, and that you were united with me in faith and spirit, and so were partakers of that exile into which Saturninus, fearing his own conscience, had thrust me after beguiling the Emperor, and after that you had denied him communion for the whole three years ago until now.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:10
verses.text: I equally rejoiced that the impious and infidel creed which was sent straightway to you from Sirmium was not only not accepted by you, but condemned as soon as reported and notified.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:11
verses.text: I felt that it was now binding on me as a religious duty to write sound and faithful words to you as my fellow-bishops, who communicate with me in Christ.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:12
verses.text: I, who through fear of what might have been could at one time only rejoice with my own conscience that I was free from all these errors, was now bound to express delight at the purity of our common faith.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:13
verses.text: Praise God for the unshaken stability of your noble hearts, for your firm house built on the foundation of the faithful rock, for the undefiled and unswerving constancy of a will that has proved immaculate! For since the good profession at the Council of Biterrae, where I denounced the ringleaders of this heresy with some of you for my witnesses, it has remained and still continues to remain, pure, unspotted and scrupulous.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:14
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:15
verses.text: You awaited the noble triumph of a holy and steadfast perseverance without yielding to the threats, the powers and the assaults of Saturninus: and when all the waves of awakening blasphemy struggled against God, you who still remain with me faithful in Christ did not give way when threatened with the onset of heresy, and now by meeting that onset you have broken all its violence.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:16
verses.text: Yes, brethren, you have conquered, to the abundant joy of those who share your faith: and your unimpaired constancy gained the double glory of keeping a pure conscience and giving an authoritative example.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:17
verses.text: For the fame of your unswerving and unshaken faith has moved certain Eastern bishops, late though it be, to some shame for the heresy fostered and supported in those regions: and when they heard of the godless confession composed at Sirmium, they contradicted its audacious authors by passing certain decrees themselves.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:18
verses.text: And though they withstood them not without in their turn raising some scruples, and inflicting some wounds upon a sensitive piety, yet they withstood them so vigorously as to compel those who at Sirmium yielded to the views of Potamius and Hosius as accepting and confirming those views, to declare their ignorance and error in so doing; in fact they had to condemn in writing their own action.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:19
verses.text: And they subscribed with the express purpose of condemning something else in advance.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:20
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:21
verses.text: But your invincible faith keeps the honourable distinction of conscious worth, and content with repudiating crafty, vague, or hesitating action, safely abides in Christ, preserving the profession of its liberty.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:22
verses.text: You abstain from communion with those who oppose their bishops with their blasphemies and keep them in exile, and do not by assenting to any crafty subterfuge bring yourselves under a charge of unrighteous judgment.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:23
verses.text: For since we all suffered deep and grievous pain at the actions of the wicked against God, within our boundaries alone is communion in Christ to be found from the time that the Church began to be harried by disturbances such as the expatriation of bishops, the deposition of priests, the intimidation of the people, the threatening of the faith, and the determination of the meaning of Christ's doctrine by human will and power.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:24
verses.text: Your resolute faith does not pretend to be ignorant of these facts or profess that it can tolerate them, perceiving that by the act of hypocritical assent it would bring itself before the bar of conscience.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:25
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:26
verses.text: And although in all your actions, past and present, you bear witness to the uninterrupted independence and security of your faith; yet in particular you prove your warmth and fervour of spirit by the fact that some of you whose letters have succeeded in reaching me have expressed a wish that I, unfit as I am, should notify to you what the Easterns have since said in their confessions of faith.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:27
verses.text: They affectionately laid the additional burden upon me of indicating my sentiments on all their decisions.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:28
verses.text: I know that my skill and learning are inadequate, for I feel it most difficult to express in words my own belief as I understand it in my heart; far less easy must it be to expound the statements of others.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:29
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:30
verses.text: Now I beseech you by the mercy of the Lord, that as I will in this letter according to your desire write to you of divine things and of the witness of a pure conscience to our faith, no one will think to judge me by the beginning of my letter before he has read the conclusion of my argument.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:31
verses.text: For it is unfair before the complete argument has been grasped, to conceive a prejudice on account of initial statements, the reason of which is yet unknown, since it is not with imperfect statements before us that we must make a decision for the sake of investigation, but on the conclusion for the sake of knowledge.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:32
verses.text: I have some fear, not about you, as God is witness of my heart, but about some who in their own esteem are very cautious and prudent but do not understand the blessed apostle's precept not to think of themselves more highly than they ought: for I am afraid that they are unwilling to know all those facts, the complete account of which I will offer at the end, and at the same time they avoid drawing the true conclusion from the aforesaid facts.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:33
verses.text: But whoever takes up these lines to read and examine them has only to be consistently patient with me and with himself and peruse the whole to its completion.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:34
verses.text: Perchance all this assertion of my faith will result in those who conceal their heresy being unable to practise the deception they wish, and in true Catholics attaining the object which they desire.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:35
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:36
verses.text: Therefore I comply with your affectionate and urgent wish, and I have set down all the creeds which have been promulgated at different times and places since the holy Council of Nicaea, with my appended explanations of all the phrases and even words employed.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:37
verses.text: If they be thought to contain anything faulty, no one can impute the fault to me: for I am only a reporter, as you wished me to be, and not an author.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:38
verses.text: But if anything is found to be laid down in right and apostolic fashion, no one can doubt that it is no credit to the interpreter but to the originator.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:39
verses.text: In any case I have sent you a faithful account of these transactions: it is for you to determine by the decision your faith inspires whether their spirit is Catholic or heretical.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:40
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:41
verses.text: For although it was necessary to reply to your letters, in which you offered me Christian communion with your faith, (and, moreover, certain of your number who were summoned to the Council which seemed pending in Bithynia did refuse with firm consistency of faith to hold communion with any but myself outside Gaul), it also seemed fit to use my episcopal office and authority, when heresy was so rife, in submitting to you by letter some godly and faithful counsel.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:42
verses.text: For the word of God cannot be exiled as our bodies are, or so chained and bound that it cannot be imparted to you in any place.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:43
verses.text: But when I had learnt that synods were to meet in Ancyra and Ariminum, and that one or two bishops from each province in Gaul would assemble there, I thought it especially needful that I, who am confined in the East, should explain and make known to you the grounds of those mutual suspicious which exist between us and the Eastern bishops, though some of you know those grounds; in order that whereas you had condemned and they had anathematized this heresy that spreads from Sirmium, you might nevertheless know with what confession of faith the Eastern bishops had come to the same result that you had come to, and that I might prevent you, whom I hope to see as shining lights in future Councils, differing, through a mistake about words, even a hair's-breadth from pure Catholic belief, when your interpretation of the apostolic faith is identically the same and you are Catholics at heart.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:44
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:45
verses.text: Now it seems to me right and appropriate, before I begin my argument about suspicions and dissensions as to words, to give as complete an account as possible of the decisions of the Eastern bishops adverse to the heresy compiled at Sirmium.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:46
verses.text: Others have published all these transactions very plainly, but much obscurity is caused by a translation from Greek into Latin, and to be absolutely literal is to be sometimes partly unintelligible.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:47
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:48
verses.text: You remember that in the Blasphemia, lately written at Sirmium, the object of the authors was to proclaim the Father to be the one and only God of all things, and deny the Son to be God: and while they determined that men should hold their peace about ὁμοούσιον and ὁμοιούσιον, they determined that God the Son should be asserted to be born not of God the Father, but of nothing, as the first creatures were, or of another essence than God, as the later creatures.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:49
verses.text: And further that in saying the Father was greater in honour, dignity, splendour and majesty, they implied that the Son lacked those things which constitute the Father's superiority.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:50
verses.text: Lastly, that while it is affirmed that His birth is unknowable, we were commanded by this Compulsory Ignorance Act not to know that He is of God: just as if it could be commanded or decreed that a man should know what in future he is to be ignorant of, or be ignorant of what he already knows.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:51
verses.text: I have subjoined in full this pestilent and godless blasphemy, though against my will, to facilitate a more complete knowledge of the worth and reason of the replies made on the opposite side by those Easterns who endeavoured to counteract all the wiles of the heretics according to their understanding and comprehension.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:52
verses.text: A copy of the Blasphemiacomposed at Sirmium by Osius and Polamius.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:53
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:54
verses.text: Since there appeared to be some misunderstanding respecting the faith, all points have been carefully investigated and discussed at Sirmium in the presence of our most reverend brothers and fellow-bishops, Valens, Ursacius and Germinius.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:55
verses.text: It is evident that there is one God, the Father Almighty, according as it is believed throughout the whole world; and His only Son Jesus Christ our Saviour, begotten of Him before the ages.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:56
verses.text: But we cannot and ought not to say that there are two Gods, for the Lord Himself said, I will go unto My Father and your Father, unto My God and your God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:57
verses.text: So there is one God over all, as the Apostle hath taught us, Is He God of the Jews only? Is He not also of the Gentiles? Yes, of the Gentiles also: seeing it is one God, which shall justify the circumcision by faith, and the uncircumcision through faith.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:58
verses.text: And in all other things they agreed thereto, nor would they allow any difference.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:59
verses.text: But since some or many persons were disturbed by questions concerning substance, called in Greek οὐσία, that is, to make it understood more exactly, as to ὁμοούσιον, or what is called ὁμοιούσιον , there ought to be no mention made of these at all.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:60
verses.text: Nor ought any exposition to be made of them for the reason and consideration that they are not contained in the divine Scriptures, and that they are above man's understanding, nor can any man declare the birth of the Son, of whom it is written, Who shall declare His generation? For it is plain that only the Father knows how He begot the Son, and the Son how He was begotten of the Father.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:61
verses.text: There is no question that the Father is greater.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:62
verses.text: No one can doubt that the Father is greater than the Son in honour, dignity, splendour, majesty, and in the very name of Father, the Son Himself testifying, He that sent Me is greater than I.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:63
verses.text: And no one is ignorant that it is Catholic doctrine that there are two Persons of Father and Son; and that the Father is greater, and that the Son is subordinated to the Father, together with all things which the Father has subordinated to Him, and that the Father has no beginning and is invisible, immortal and impassible, but that the Son has been begotten of the Father, God of God, Light of Light, and that the generation of this Son, as is aforesaid, no one knows but His Father.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:64
verses.text: And that the Son of God Himself, our Lord and God, as we read, took flesh, that is, a body, that is, man of the womb of the Virgin Mary, of the Angel announced.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:65
verses.text: And as all the Scriptures teach, and especially the doctor of the Gentiles himself, He took of Mary the Virgin, man, through whom He suffered.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:66
verses.text: And the whole faith is summed up and secured in this, that the Trinity must always be preserved, as we read in the Gospel, Go ye and baptize all nations in the Name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:67
verses.text: Complete and perfect is the number of the Trinity.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:68
verses.text: How the Paraclete, the Spirit, is through the Son: Who was sent and came according to His promise in order to instruct, teach and sanctify the apostles and all believers.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:69
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:70
verses.text: After these many and most impious statements had been made, the Eastern bishops on their side again met together and composed definitions of their confession.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:71
verses.text: Since, however, we have frequently to mention the words essence and substance, we must determine the meaning of essence, lest in discussing facts we prove ignorant of the signification of our words.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:72
verses.text: Essence is a reality which is, or the reality of those things from which it is, and which subsists inasmuch as it is permanent.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:73
verses.text: Now we can speak of the essence, or nature, or genus, or substance of anything.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:74
verses.text: And the strict reason why the word essence is employed is because it is always.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:75
verses.text: But this is identical with substance, because a thing which is, necessarily subsists in itself, and whatever thus subsists possesses unquestionably a permanent genus, nature or substance.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:76
verses.text: When, therefore, we say that essence signifies nature, or genus, or substance, we mean the essence of that thing which permanently exists in the nature, genus, or substance.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:77
verses.text: Now, therefore, let us review the definitions of faith drawn up by the Easterns.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:78
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:79
verses.text: "If any one hearing that the Son is the image of the invisible God, says that the image of God is the same as the invisible God, as though refusing to confess that He is truly Son: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:80
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:81
verses.text: Hereby is excluded the assertion of those who wish to represent the relationship of Father and Son as a matter of names, inasmuch as every image is similar in species to that of which it is an image.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:82
verses.text: For no one is himself his own image, but it is necessary that the image should demonstrate him of whom it is an image.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:83
verses.text: So an image is the figured and indistinguishable likeness of one thing equated with another.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:84
verses.text: Therefore the Father is, and the Son is, because the Son is the image of the Father: and he who is an image, if he is to be truly an image, must have in himself his original's species, nature and essence in virtue of the fact that he is an image.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:85
verses.text: II.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:86
verses.text: "And if any one hearing the Son say, As the Father hath life in Himself, so also hath He given to the Son to have life in Himself, shall say that He who has received life from the Father, and who also declares, I live by the Father, is the same as He who gave life: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:87
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:88
verses.text: The person of the recipient and of the giver are distinguished so that the same should not be made one and sole.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:89
verses.text: For since he is under anathema who has believed that, when recipient and giver are mentioned one solitary and unique person is implied, we may not suppose that the selfsame person who gave received from Himself.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:90
verses.text: For He who lives and He through whom He lives are not identical, for one lives to Himself, the other declares that He lives through the Author of His life, and no one will declare that He who enjoys life and He through whom His life is caused are personally identical.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:91
verses.text: III.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:92
verses.text: "And if any one hearing that the Only-begotten Son is like the invisible God, denies that the Son who is the image of the invisible God (whose image is understood to include essence) is Son in essence, as though denying His true Sonship: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:93
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:94
verses.text: It is here insisted that the nature is indistinguishable and entirely similar.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:95
verses.text: For since He is the Only-begotten Son of God and the image of the invisible God, it is necessary that He should be of an essence similar in species and nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:96
verses.text: Or what distinction can be made between Father and Son affecting their nature with its similar genus, when the Son subsisting through the nature begotten in Him is invested with the properties of the Father, viz.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:97
verses.text: , glory, worth, power, invisibility, essence? And while these prerogatives of divinity are equal we neither understand the one to be less because He is Son, nor the other to be greater because He is Father; since the Son is the image of the Father in species, and not dissimilar in genus; since the similarity of a Son begotten of the substance of His Father does not admit of any diversity of substance, and the Son and image of the invisible God embraces in Himself the whole form of His Father's divinity both in kind and in amount: and this is to be truly Son, to reflect the truth of the Father's form by the perfect likeness of the nature imaged in Himself.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:98
verses.text: IV.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:99
verses.text: "And if any one hearing this text, For as the Father hath life in Himself so also He hath given to the Son to have life in Himself; denies that the Son is like the Father even in essence, though He testifies that it is even as He has said; let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:100
verses.text: For it is plain that since the life which is understood to exist in the Father signifies substance, and the life of the Only-begotten which was begotten of the Father is also understood to mean substance or essence, He there signifies a likeness of essence to essence".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:101
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:102
verses.text: With the Son's origin as thus stated is connected the perfect birth of the undivided nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:103
verses.text: For what in each is life, that in each is signified by essence.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:104
verses.text: And in the life which is begotten of life, i-e: in the essence which is born of essence, seeing that it is not born unlike (and that because life is of life), He keeps in Himself a nature wholly similar to His original, because there is no diversity in the likeness of the essence that is born and that begets, that is, of the life which is possessed and which has been given.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:105
verses.text: For though God begat Him of Himself, in likeness to His own nature, He in whom is the unbegotten likeness did not relinquish the property of His natural substance.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:106
verses.text: For He only has what He gave; and as possessing life He gave life to be possessed.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:107
verses.text: And thus what is born of essence, as life of life, is essentially like itself, and the essence of Him who is begotten and of Him who begets admits no diversity or unlikeness.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:108
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:109
verses.text: "If any one hearing the words formed or created it and begat me spoken by the same lips, refuses to understand this begat me of likeness of essence, but says that begat me and formed me are the same: as if to deny that the perfect Son of God was here signified as Son under two different expressions, as Wisdom has given us to piously understand, and asserts that formed me and begat me only imply formation and not sonship: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:110
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:111
verses.text: Those who say that the Son of God is only a creature or formation are opposed on the fact that they say they have read The Lord formed or created me, which seems to imply formation or creation; but they omit the following sentence, which is the key to the first, and from the first wrest authority for their impious statement that the Son is a creature, because Wisdom has said that she was created.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:112
verses.text: But if she were created, how could she be also born? For all birth, of whatever kind, attains its own nature from the nature that begets it: but creation takes its beginning from the power of the Creator, the Creator being able to form a creature from nothing.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:113
verses.text: So Wisdom, who said that she was created, does in the next sentence say that she was also begotten, using the word creation of the act of the changeless nature of her Parent, which nature, unlike the manner and wont of human parturition, without any detriment or change of self created from itself what it begat.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:114
verses.text: Similarly a Creator has no need of passion or intercourse or parturition.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:115
verses.text: And that which is created out of nothing begins to exist at a definite moment.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:116
verses.text: And He who creates makes His object through His mere power, and creation is the work of might, not the birth of a nature from a nature that besets it.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:117
verses.text: But because the Son of God was not begotten after the manner of corporeal childbearing, but was born perfect God of perfect God; therefore Wisdom says that she was created, excluding in her manner of birth every kind of corporeal process.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:118
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:119
verses.text: Moreover, to shew that she possesses a nature that was born and not created, Wisdom has added that she was begotten, that by declaring that she was created and also begotten, she might completely explain her birth.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:120
verses.text: By speaking of creation she implies that the nature of the Father is changeless, and she also shews that the substance of her nature begotten of God the Father is genuine and real.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:121
verses.text: And so her words about creation and generation have explained the perfection of her birth: the former that the Father is changeless, the latter the reality of her own nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:122
verses.text: The two things combined become one, and that one is both in perfection: for the Son being born of God without any change in God, is so born of the Father as to be created; and the Father, who is changeless in Himself and the Son's Father by nature, so forms the Son as to beget Him.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:123
verses.text: Therefore the heresy which has dared to aver that the Son of God is a creature is condemned because while the first statement shews the impossible perfection of the divinity, the second, which asserts His natural generation, crushes the impious opinion that He was created out of nothing.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:124
verses.text: VI.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:125
verses.text: "And if any one grant the Son only a likeness of activity, but rob Him of the likeness of essence which is the corner-stone of our faith, in spite of the fact that the Son Himself reveals His essential likeness with the Father in the words, For as the Father hath life in Himself, so also hath He given to the Son to have life in Himself, as well as His likeness in activity by teaching us that What things soever the Father doeth, these also doeth the Son likewise, such a man robs himself of the knowledge of eternal life which is in the Father and the Son, and let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:126
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:127
verses.text: The heretics when beset by authoritative passages in Scripture are wont only to grant that the Son is like the Father in might while they deprive Him of similarity of nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:128
verses.text: This is foolish and impious, for they do not understand that similar might can only be the result of a similar nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:129
verses.text: For a lower nature can never attain to the might of a higher and more powerful nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:130
verses.text: What will the men who make these assertions say about the omnipotence of God the Father, if the might of a lower nature is made equal to His own? For they cannot deny that the Son's power is the same, seeing that He has said What things soever the Father doeth, these also doeth the Son likewise.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:131
verses.text: No, a similarity of nature follows on a similarity of might when He says, As the Father hath life in Himself, so also hath He given to the Son to have life in Himself.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:132
verses.text: In life is implied nature and essence; this, Christ teaches, has been given Him to have as the Father hath.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:133
verses.text: Therefore similarity of life contains similarity of might: for there cannot be similarity of life where the nature is dissimilar.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:134
verses.text: So it is necessary that similarity of essence follows on similarity of might: for as what the Father does, the Son does also, so the life that the Father has He has given to the Son to have likewise.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:135
verses.text: Therefore we condemn the rash and impious statements of those who confess a similarity of might but have dared to preach a dissimilarity of nature, since it is the chief ground of our hope to confess that in the Father and the Son there is an identical divine substance.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:136
verses.text: VII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:137
verses.text: "And if any one professing that he believes that there is a Father and a Son, says that the Father is Father of an essence unlike Himself but of similar activity; for speaking profane and novel words against the essence of the Son and nullifying His true divine Sonship, let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:138
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:139
verses.text: By confused and involved expressions the heretics very frequently elude the truth and secure the ears of the unwary by the mere sound of common words, such as the titles Father and Son, which they do not truthfully utter to express a natural and genuine community of essence: for they are aware that God is called the Father of all creation, and remember that all the saints are named sons of God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:140
verses.text: In like manner they declare that the relationship between the Father and the Son resembles that between the Father and the universe, so that the names Father and Son are rather titular than real.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:141
verses.text: For the names are titular if the Persons have a distinct nature of a different essence, since no reality can be attached to the name of father unless it be based on the nature of his offspring.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:142
verses.text: So the Father cannot be called Father of an alien substance unlike His own, for a perfect birth manifests no diversity between itself and the original substance.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:143
verses.text: Therefore we repudiate all the impious assertions that the Father is Father of a Son begotten of Himself and yet not of His own nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:144
verses.text: We shall not call God Father for having a creature like Him in might and activity, but for begetting a nature of an essence not unlike or alien to Himself: for a natural birth does not admit of any dissimilarity with the Father's nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:145
verses.text: Therefore those are anathema who assert that the Father is Father of a nature unlike Himself, so that something other than God is born of God, and who suppose that the essence of the Father degenerated in begetting the Son.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:146
verses.text: For so far as in them lies they destroy the very birthless and changeless essence of the Father by daring to attribute to Him in the birth of His Only-begotten an alteration and degeneration of His natural essence.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:147
verses.text: VIII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:148
verses.text: "And if any one understanding that the Son is like in essence to Him whose Son He is admitted to be, says that the Son is the same as the Father, or part of the Father, or that it is through an emanation or any such passion as is necessary for the procreation of corporeal children that the incorporeal Son draws His life from the incorporeal Father: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:149
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:150
verses.text: We have always to beware of the vices of particular perversions, and countenance no opportunity for delusion.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:151
verses.text: For many heretics say that the Son is like the Father in divinity in order to support the theory that in virtue of this similarity the Son is the same Person as the Father: for this undivided similarity appears to countenance a belief in a single monad.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:152
verses.text: For what does not differ in kind seems to retain identity of nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:153
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:154
verses.text: But birth does not countenance this vain imagination; for such identity without differentiation excludes birth.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:155
verses.text: For what is born has a father who caused its birth.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:156
verses.text: Nor because the divinity of Him who is being born is inseparable from that of Him who begets, are the Begetter and the Begotten the same Person; while on the other hand He who is born and He who begets cannot be unlike.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:157
verses.text: He is therefore anathema who shall proclaim a similarity of nature in the Father and the Son in order to abolish the personal meaning of the word Son: for while through mutual likeness one differs in no respect from the other, yet this very likeness, which does not admit of bare union, confesses both the Father and the Son because the Son is the changeless likeness of the Father.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:158
verses.text: For the Son is not part of the Father so that He who is born and He who begets can be called one Person.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:159
verses.text: Nor is He an emanation so that by a continual flow of a corporeal uninterrupted stream the flow is itself kept in its source, the source being identical with the flow in virtue of the successive and unbroken continuity.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:160
verses.text: But the birth is perfect, and remains alike in nature; not taking its beginning materially from a corporeal conception and bearing, but as an incorporeal Son drawing His existence from an incorporeal Father according to the likeness which belongs to an identical nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:161
verses.text: IX.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:162
verses.text: "And if any one, because the Father is never admitted to be the Son and the Son is never admitted to be the Father, when he says that the Son is other than the Father (because the Father is one Person and the Son another, inasmuch as it is said, There is another that beareth witness of Me, even the father who sent Me), does in anxiety for the distinct personal qualities of the Father and the Son which in the Church must be piously understood to exist, fear that the Son and the Father may sometimes be admitted to be the same Person, and therefore denies that the Son is like in essence to the Father: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:163
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:164
verses.text: It was said unto the apostles of the Lord, Be ye wise as serpents, and harmless as doves.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:165
verses.text: Christ therefore wished there to be in us the nature of different creatures: but in such a sort that the harmlessness of the dove might temper the serpent's wisdom, and the wisdom of the serpent might instruct the harmlessness of the dove, and that so wisdom might be made harmless and harmlessness wise.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:166
verses.text: This precept has been observed in the exposition of this creed.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:167
verses.text: For the former sentence of which we have spoken guarded against the teaching of a unity of person under the cloak of an essential likeness, and against the denial of the Son's birth as the result of an identity of nature, lest we should understand God to be a single monad because one Person does not differ in kind from the other.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:168
verses.text: In the next sentence, by harmless and apostolic wisdom we have again taken refuge in that wisdom of the serpent to which we are bidden to be conformed no less than to the harmlessness of the dove, lest perchance through a repudiation of the unity of persons on the ground that the Father is one Person and the Son another, a preaching of the dissimilarity of their natures should again take us unawares, and lest on the ground that He who sent and He who was sent are two Persons (for the Sent and the Sender cannot be one Person) they should be considered to have divided and dissimilar natures, though He who is born and He who begets Him cannot be of a different essence.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:169
verses.text: So we preserve in Father and in Son the likeness of an identical nature through an essential birth: yet the similarity of nature does not injure personality by making the Sent and the Sender to be but one.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:170
verses.text: Nor do we do away with the similarity of nature by admitting distinct personal qualities, for it is impossible that the one God should be called Son and Father to Himself.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:171
verses.text: So then the truth as to the birth supports the similarity of essence and the similarity of essence does not undermine the personal reality of the birth.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:172
verses.text: Nor again does a profession of belief in the Begetter and the Begotten exclude a similarity of essence; for while the Begetter and the Begotten cannot be one Person, He who is born and He who begets cannot be of a different nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:173
verses.text: X.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:174
verses.text: "And if any one admits that God became Father of the Only-begotten Son at any point in time and not that the Only-begotten Son came into existence without passion beyond all times and beyond all human calculation: for contravening the teaching of the Gospel which scorned any interval of times between the being of the Father and the Son and faithfully has instructed us that In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God, let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:175
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:176
verses.text: It is a pious saying that the Father is not limited by times: for the true meaning of the name of Father which He bore before time began surpasses comprehension.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:177
verses.text: Although religion teaches us to ascribe to Him this name of Father through which comes the impassible origin of the Son, yet He is not bound in time, for the eternal and infinite God cannot be understood as having become a Father in time, and according to the teaching of the Gospel the Only-begotten God the Word is recognized even in the beginning rather to be with God than to be born.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:178
verses.text: XI.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:179
verses.text: "And if any one says that the Father is older in time than His Only-begotten Son, and that the Son is younger than the Father: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:180
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:181
verses.text: The essential likeness conformed to the Father's essence in kind is also taught to be identical in time: lest He who is the image of God, who is the Word, who is God with God in the beginning, who is like the Father, by the insertion of times between Himself and the Father should not have in Himself in perfection that which is both image, and Word, and God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:182
verses.text: For if He be proclaimed to be younger in time, He has lost the truth of the image and likeness: for that is no longer likeness which is found to be dissimilar in time.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:183
verses.text: For that very fact that God is Father prevents there being any time in which He was not Father: consequently there can be no time in the Son's existence in which He was not Son.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:184
verses.text: Wherefore we must neither call the Father older than the Son nor the Son younger than the Father: for the true meaning of neither name can exist without the other.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:185
verses.text: XII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:186
verses.text: "And if any one attributes the timeless substance (i-e: Person) of the Only-begotten Son derived from the Father to the unborn essence of God, as though calling the Father Son: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:187
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:188
verses.text: The above definition when it denied that the idea of time could be applied to the birth of the Son seemed to have given an occasion for heresy (we saw that it would be monstrous if the Father were limited by time, but that He would be so limited if the Son were subjected to time), so that by the help of this repudiation of time, the Father who is unborn might under the appellation of Son be proclaimed as both Father and Son in a single and unique Person.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:189
verses.text: For in excluding times from the Son's birth it seemed to countenance the opinion that there was no birth, so that He whose birth is not in time might be considered not to have been born at all.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:190
verses.text: Wherefore, lest at the suggestion of this denial of time the heresy of the unity of Persons should insinuate itself, that impiety is condemned which dares to refer the timeless birth to the unique and singular Person of the unborn essence.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:191
verses.text: For it is one thing to be outside time and another to be unborn; the first admits of birth (though outside time), the other, so far as it is, is the one sole author from eternity of its being what it is.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:192
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:193
verses.text: We have reviewed, beloved brethren, all the definitions of faith made by the Eastern bishops which they formulated in their assembly against the recently emerging heresy.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:194
verses.text: And we, as far as we have been able, have adapted the wording of our exposition to express their meaning, following their diction rather than desiring to be thought the originators of new phrases.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:195
verses.text: In these words they decree the principles of their conscience and a long maintained doctrine against a new and profane impiety.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:196
verses.text: Those who compiled this heresy at Sirmium, or accepted it after its compilation, they have thereby compelled to confess their ignorance and to sign such decrees.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:197
verses.text: There the Son is the perfect image of the Father: there under the qualities of an identical essence, the Person of the Son is not annihilated and confounded with the Father: there the Son is declared to be image of the Father in virtue of a real likeness, and does not differ in substance from the Father, whose image He is: there on account of the life which the Father has and the life which the Son has received, the Father can have nothing different in substance (this being implied in life) from that which the Son received to have: there the begotten Son is not a creature, but is a Person undistinguished from the Father's nature: there, just as an identical might belongs to the Father and the Son, so their essence admits of no difference: there the Father by begetting the Son in no wise degenerates from Himself in Him through any difference of nature: there, though the likeness of nature is the same in each, the proper qualities which mark this likeness are repugnant to a confusion of Persons, so that there is not one subsisting Person who is called both Father and Son: there, though it is piously affirmed that there is both a Father who sends and a Son who is sent, yet no distinction in essence is drawn between the Father and the Son, the Sent and the Sender: there the truth of God's Fatherhood is not bound by limits of time: there the Son is not later in time: there beyond all time is a perfect birth which refutes the error that the Son could not be born.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:198
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:199
verses.text: Here, beloved brethren, is the entire creed which was published by some Easterns, few in proportion to the whole number of bishops, and which first saw light at the very times when you repelled the introduction of this heresy.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:200
verses.text: The reason for its promulgation was the fact that they were bidden to say nothing of the ὁμοούσιον.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:201
verses.text: But even in former times, through the urgency of these numerous causes, it was necessary at different occasions to compose other creeds, the character of which will be understood from their wording.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:202
verses.text: For when you are fully aware of the results, it will be easier for us to bring to a full consummation, such as religion and unity demand, the argument in which we are interested.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:203
verses.text: An exposition of the faith of the Church made at the Council held on the occasion of the Dedicationof the church at Antioch by ninety-seven bishops there present, because of suspicions felt as to the orthodoxy of a certain bishop  29.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:204
verses.text: "We believe in accordance with evangelical and apostolic tradition in one God the Father Almighty, the Creator, Maker and Disposer of all things that are, and from whom are all things.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:205
verses.text: "And in one Lord Jesus Christ, His Only-begotten Son, God through whom are all things, who was begotten of the Father, God of God, whole God of whole God, One of One, perfect God of perfect God, King of King, Lord of Lord, the Word, the Wisdom, the Life, true Light, true Way, the Resurrection, the Shepherd, the Gate, unable to change or alter, the unvarying image of the essence and might and glory of the Godhead, the first-born of all creation, who always was in the beginning with God, the Word of God, according to what is said in the Gospel, and the Word was God, through whom all things were made, and in whom all things subsist, who in the last days came down from above, and was born of a virgin according to the Scriptures, and was made the Lamb, the Mediator between God and man, the Apostle of our faith, and leader of life.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:206
verses.text: For He said, I came down from heaven, not to do Mine own will, but the will of Him that sent me.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:207
verses.text: Who suffered and rose again for us on the third day, and ascended into heaven, and sitteth on the right hand of the Father, and is to come again with glory to judge the quick and the dead.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:208
verses.text: "And in the Holy Ghost, who was given to them that believe, to comfort, sanctify and perfect, even as our Lord Jesus Christ ordained His disciples, saying, Go ye, and teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost, manifestly, that is, of a Father who is truly Father, and clearly of a Son who is truly Son, and a Holy Ghost who is truly a Holy Ghost, these words not being set forth idly and without meaning, but carefully signifying the Person, and order, and glory of each of those who are named, to teach us that they are three Persons, but in agreement one.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:209
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:210
verses.text: "Having therefore held this faith from the beginning, and being resolved to hold it to the end in the sight of God and Christ, we say anathema to every heretical and perverted sect, and if any man teaches contrary to the wholesome and right faith of the Scriptures, saying that there is or was time, or space, or age before the Son was begotten, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:211
verses.text: And if any one say that the Son is a formation like one of the things that are formed, or a birth resembling other births, or a creature like the creatures, and not as the divine Scriptures have affirmed in each passage aforesaid, or teaches or proclaims as the Gospel anything else than what we have received: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:212
verses.text: For all those things which were written in the divine Scriptures by Prophets and by Apostles we believe and follow truly and with fear".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:213
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:214
verses.text: Perhaps this creed has not spoken expressly enough of the identical similarity of the Father and the Son, especially in concluding that the names Father, Son and Holy Ghost referred to the Person and order and glory of each of those who are named to teach us that they are three Persons, but in agreement one.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:215
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:216
verses.text: But in the first place we must remember that the bishops did not assemble at Antioch to oppose the heresy which has dared to declare that the substance of the Son is unlike that of the Father, but to oppose that which, in spite of the Council of Nicaea, presumed to attribute the three names to the Father.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:217
verses.text: Of this we will treat in its proper place.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:218
verses.text: I recollect that at the beginning of my argument I besought the patience and forbearance of my readers and hearers until the completion of my letter, lest any one should rashly rise to judge me before he was acquainted with the entire argument.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:219
verses.text: I ask it again.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:220
verses.text: This assembly of the saints wished to strike a blow at that impiety which by a mere counting of names evades the truth as to the Father and the Son and the Holy Ghost; which represents that there is no personal cause for each name, and by a false use of these names makes the triple nomenclature imply only one Person, so that the Father alone could be also called both Holy Ghost and Son.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:221
verses.text: Consequently they declared there were three substances, meaning three subsistent Persons, and not thereby introducing any dissimilarity of essence to separate the substance of Father and Son.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:222
verses.text: For the words to teach us that they are three in substance, but in agreement one, are free from objection, because as the Spirit is also named, and He is the Paraclete, it is more fitting that a unity of agreement should be asserted than a unity of essence based on likeness of substance.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:223
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:224
verses.text: Further the whole of the above statement has drawn no distinction whatever between the essence and nature of the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:225
verses.text: For when it is said, God of God, whole God of whole God, there is no room for doubting that whole God is born of whole God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:226
verses.text: For the nature of God who is of God admits of no difference, and as whole God of whole God He is in all in which the Father is.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:227
verses.text: One of One excludes the passions of a human birth and conception, so that since He is One of One, He comes from no other source, nor is different nor alien, for He is One of One, perfect God of perfect God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:228
verses.text: Except in having a cause of its origin His birth does not differ from the birthless nature since the perfection of both Persons is the same.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:229
verses.text: King of King.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:230
verses.text: A power that is expressed by one and the same title allows no dissimilarity of power.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:231
verses.text: Lord of Lord.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:232
verses.text: In 'Lord' also the lordship is equal: there can be no difference where domination is confessed of both without diversity.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:233
verses.text: But plainest of all is the statement appended after several others, unable to change or alter, the unvarying image of the Godhead and essence and might and glory.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:234
verses.text: For as God of God, whole God of whole God, One of One, perfect God of perfect God, King of King and Lord of Lord, since in all that glory and nature of Godhead in which the Father ever abides, the Son born of Him also subsists; He derives this also from the Father's substance that He is unable to change.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:235
verses.text: For in His birth that nature from which He is born is not changed; but the Son has maintained a changeless essence since His origin is in a changeless nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:236
verses.text: For though He is an image, yet the image cannot alter, since in Him was born the image of the Father's essence, and there could not be in Him a change of nature caused by any unlikeness to the Father's essence from which He was begotten.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:237
verses.text: Now when we are taught that He was brought into being as the first of all creation, and He is Himself said to have always been in the beginning with God as God the Word, the fact that He was brought into being shews that He was born, and the fact that He always was, shews that He is not separated from the Father by time.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:238
verses.text: Therefore this Council by dividing the three substances, which it did to exclude a monad God with a threefold title, did not introduce any separation of substance between the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:239
verses.text: The whole exposition of faith makes no distinction between Father and Son, the Unborn and the Only-begotten, in time, or name, or essence, or dignity, or domination.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:240
verses.text: But our common conscience demands that we should gain a knowledge of the other creeds of the same Eastern bishops, composed at different times and places, that by the study of many confessions we may understand the sincerity of their faith.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:241
verses.text: The Creed according to the Council of the East.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:242
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:243
verses.text: "We, the holy synod met in Sardica from different provinces of the East, namely, Thebais, Egypt, Palestine, Arabia, Phoenicia, Coele Syria, Mesopotamia, Cilicia, Cappadocia, Pontus, Paphlagonia, Galatia, Bithynia and Hellespont, from Asia, namely, the two provinces of Phrygia, Pisidia, the islands of the Cyclades, Pamphylia, Caria, Lydia, from Europe, namely, Thrace, Haemimontus, Moesia, and the two provinces of Pannonia, have set forth this creed.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:244
verses.text: "We believe in one God, the Father Almighty, Creator and Maker of all things, from whom all fatherhood in heaven and earth is named:  "And we believe in His Only-begotten Son our Lord Jesus Christ, who before all ages was begotten of the Father, God of God, Light of Light, through whom were made all things which are in heaven and earth, visible and invisible: who is the Word and Wisdom and Might and Life and true Light: and who in the last days for our sake was incarnate, and was born of the holy Virgin, who was crucified and dead and buried, And rose from the dead on the third day, And was received into heaven, And sitteth on the right hand of the Father, And shall come to judge the quick and the dead and to give to every man according to his works: Whose kingdom remaineth without end for ever and ever.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:245
verses.text: For He sitteth on the right hand of the Father not only in this age, but also in the age to come.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:246
verses.text: "We believe also in the Holy Ghost, that is, the Paraclete, whom according to His promise He sent to His apostles after His return into the heavens to teach them and to bring all things to their remembrance, through whom also the souls of them that believe sincerely in Him are sanctified.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:247
verses.text: "But those who say that the Son of God is sprung from things non-existent or from another substance and not from God, and that there was a time or age when He was not, the holy Catholic Church holds them as aliens.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:248
verses.text: Likewise also those who say that there are three Gods, or that Christ is not God and that before the ages He was neither Christ nor Son of God, or that He Himself is the Father and the Son and the Holy Ghost, or that the Son is incapable of birth; or that the Father begat the Son without purpose or will: the holy Catholic Church anathematizes".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:249
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:250
verses.text: In the exposition of this creed, concise but complete definitions have been employed.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:251
verses.text: For in condemning those who said that the Son sprang from things non-existent, it attributed to Him a source which had no beginning but continues perpetually.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:252
verses.text: And lest this source from which He drew His permanent birth should be understood to be any other substance than that of God, it also declares to be blasphemers those who said that the Son was born of some other substance and not of God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:253
verses.text: And so since He does not draw His subsistence from nothing, or spring from any other source than God, it cannot be doubted that He was born with those qualities which are God's; since the Only-begotten essence of the Son is generated neither from things which are non-existent nor from any other substance than the birthless and eternal substance of the Father.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:254
verses.text: But the creed also rejects intervals of times or ages: on the assumption that He who does not differ in nature cannot be separable by time.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:255
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:256
verses.text: On every side, where anxiety might be felt, approach is barred to the arguments of heretics lest it should be declared that there is any difference in the Son.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:257
verses.text: For those are anathematized who say that there are three Gods: because according to God's true nature His substance does not admit a number of applications of the title, except as it is given to individual men and angels in recognition of their merit, though the substance of their nature and that of God is different.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:258
verses.text: In that sense there are consequently many gods.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:259
verses.text: Furthermore in the nature of God, God is one, yet in such a way that the Son also is God, because in Him there is not a different nature: and since He is God of God, both must be God, and since there is no difference of kind between them there is no distinction in their essence.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:260
verses.text: A number of titular Gods is rejected; because there is no diversity in the quality of the divine nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:261
verses.text: Since therefore he is anathema who says there are many Gods and he is anathema who denies that the Son is God; it is fully shewn that the fact that each has one and the same name arises from the real character of the similar substance in each: since in confessing the Unborn God the Father, and the Only-begotten God the Son, with no dissimilarity of essence between them, each is called God, yet God must be believed and be declared to be one.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:262
verses.text: So by the diligent and watchful care of the bishops the creed guards the similarity of the nature begotten and the nature begetting, confirming it by the application of one name.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:263
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:264
verses.text: Yet to prevent the declaration of one God seeming to affirm that God is a solitary monad without offspring of His own, it immediately condemns the rash suggestion that because God is one, therefore God the Father is one and solitary, having in Himself the name of Father and of Son: since in the Father who begets and the Son who comes to birth one God must be declared to exist on account of the substance of their nature being similar in each.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:265
verses.text: The faith of the saints knows nothing of the Son being incapable of birth: because the nature of the Son only draws its existence from birth.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:266
verses.text: But the nature of the birth is in Him so perfect that He who was born of the substance of God is born also of His purpose and will.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:267
verses.text: For from His will and purpose, not from the process of a corporeal nature, springs the absolute perfection of the essence of God born from the essence of God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:268
verses.text: It follows that we should now consider that creed which was compiled not long ago when Photinus was deposed from the episcopate.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:269
verses.text: A copy of the creed composed at Sirmium by the Easterns to oppose Photinus.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:270
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:271
verses.text: "We believe in one God the Father Almighty, the Creator and Maker, from whom every fatherhood in heaven and in earth is named.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:272
verses.text: "And in His only Son Jesus Christ our Lord, who was born of the Father before all ages, God of God, Light of Light, through whom all things were made in heaven and in earth, visible and invisible.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:273
verses.text: Who is the Word and Wisdom and Might and Life and true Light: who in the last days for our sake took a body, And was born of the holy Virgin, And was crucified, And was dead and buried: who also rose from the dead on the third day, And ascended into heaven, And sitteth on the right hand of the Father, And shall come at the end of the world to judge the quick and the dead; whose kingdom continueth without end and remaineth for perpetual ages.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:274
verses.text: For He shall be sitting at the right hand of the Father not only in this age, but also in the age to come.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:275
verses.text: "And in the Holy Ghost, that is, the Paraclete, whom according to His promise He sent to the apostles after He ascended into heaven to teach them and to remind them of all things, through whom also are sanctified the souls of those who believe sincerely in Him.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:276
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:277
verses.text: "But those who say that the Son is sprung from things non-existent, or from another substance and not from God, and that there was a time or age when He was not, the holy Catholic Church regards as aliens.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:278
verses.text: II.
