verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:279
verses.text: "If any man says that the Father and the Son are two Gods: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:280
verses.text: III.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:281
verses.text: "And if any man says that God is one, but does not confess that Christ, God the Son of God, ministered to the Father in the creation of all things: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:282
verses.text: IV.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:283
verses.text: "And if any man dares to say that the Unborn God, or a part of Him, was born of Mary: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:284
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:285
verses.text: "And if any man say that the Son born of Mary was, before born of Mary, Son only according to foreknowledge or predestination, and denies that He was born of the Father before the ages and was with God, and that all things were made through Him: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:286
verses.text: VI.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:287
verses.text: "If any man says that the substance of God is expanded and contracted: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:288
verses.text: VII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:289
verses.text: "If any man says that the expanded substance of God makes the Son; or names Son His supposed expanded substance: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:290
verses.text: VIII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:291
verses.text: "If any man says that the Son of God is the internal or uttered Word of God: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:292
verses.text: IX.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:293
verses.text: "If any man says that the man alone born of Mary is the Son: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:294
verses.text: X.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:295
verses.text: "If any man though saying that God and Man was born of Mary, understands thereby the Unborn God: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:296
verses.text: XI.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:297
verses.text: "If any man hearing The Word was made Fleshthinks that the Word was transformed into Flesh, or says that He suffered change in taking Flesh: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:298
verses.text: XII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:299
verses.text: "If any man hearing that the only Son of God was crucified, says that His divinity suffered corruption, or pain, or change, or diminution, or destruction: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:300
verses.text: XIII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:301
verses.text: "If any man says Let us make manwas not spoken by the Father to the Son, but by God to Himself: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:302
verses.text: XIV.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:303
verses.text: "If any man says that the Son did not appear to Abraham, but the Unborn God, or a part of Him: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:304
verses.text: XV.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:305
verses.text: "If any man says that the Son did not wrestle with Jacob as a man, but the Unborn God, or a part of Him: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:306
verses.text: XVI.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:307
verses.text: "If any man does not understand The Lord rained from the Lord to be spoken of the Father and the Son, but that the Father rained from Himself: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:308
verses.text: For the Lord the Son rained from the Lord the Father.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:309
verses.text: XVII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:310
verses.text: "If any man says that the Lord and the Lord, the Father and the Son are two Gods, because of the aforesaid words: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:311
verses.text: For we do not make the Son the equal or peer of the Father, but understand the Son to be subject.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:312
verses.text: For He did not come down to Sodom without the Father's will, nor rain from Himself but from the Lord, to wit by the Father's authority; nor does He sit at the Father's right hand by His own authority, but He hears the Father saying.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:313
verses.text: Sit thou on My right hand.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:314
verses.text: XVIII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:315
verses.text: "If any man says that the Father and the Son and the Holy Ghost are one Person: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:316
verses.text: XIX.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:317
verses.text: "If any man speaking of the Holy Ghost the Paraclete says that He is the Unborn God: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:318
verses.text: XX.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:319
verses.text: "If any man denies that, as the Lord has taught us, the Paraclete is different from the Son; for He said, And the Father shall send you another Comforter, whom I shall ask: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:320
verses.text: XXI.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:321
verses.text: "If any man says that the Holy Spirit is a part of the Father or of the Son: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:322
verses.text: XXII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:323
verses.text: "If any man says that the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit are three Gods: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:324
verses.text: XXIII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:325
verses.text: "If any man after the example of the Jews understands as said for the destruction of the Eternal Only-begotten God the words, I am the first God, and I am the last God, and beside Me there is no God, which were spoken for the destruction of idols and them that are no gods: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:326
verses.text: XXIV.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:327
verses.text: "If any man says that the Son was made by the will of God, like any object in creation: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:328
verses.text: XXV.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:329
verses.text: "If any man says that the Son was born against the will of the Father: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:330
verses.text: For the Father was not forced against His own will, or induced by any necessity of nature to beget the Son: but as soon as He willed, before time and without passion He begat Him of Himself and shewed Him forth.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:331
verses.text: XXVI.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:332
verses.text: "If any man says that the Son is incapable of birth and without beginning, saying as though there were two incapable of birth and unborn and without beginning, and makes two Gods: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:333
verses.text: For the Head, which is the beginning of all things, is the Son; but the Head or beginning of Christ is God: for so to One who is without beginning and is the beginning of all things, we refer the whole world through Christ.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:334
verses.text: XXVII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:335
verses.text: "Once more we strengthen the understanding of Christianity by saying, If any man denies that Christ who is God and Son of God, personally existed before time began and aided the Father in the perfecting of all things; but says that only from the time that He was born of Mary did He gain the name of Christ and Son and a beginning of His deity: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:336
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:337
verses.text: The necessity of the moment urged the Council to set forth a wider and broader exposition of the creed including many intricate questions, because the heresy which Photinus was reviving was sapping our Catholic home by many secret mines.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:338
verses.text: Their purpose was to oppose every form of stealthy subtle heresy by a corresponding form of pure and unsullied faith, and to have as many complete explanations of the faith as there were instances of peculiar faithlessness.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:339
verses.text: Immediately after the universal and unquestioned statement of the Christian mysteries, the explanation of the faith against the heretics begins as follows.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:340
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:341
verses.text: "But those who say that the Son is sprung from things non-existent, or from another substance and not from God, and that there was a time or age when He was not, the holy Catholic Church regards as aliens".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:342
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:343
verses.text: What ambiguity is there here? What is omitted that the consciousness of a sincere faith could suggest? He does not spring from things non-existent: therefore His origin has existence.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:344
verses.text: There is no other substance extant to be His origin, but that of God: therefore nothing else can be born in Him but all that is God; because His existence is not from nothing, and He draws subsistence from no other source.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:345
verses.text: He does not differ in time: therefore the Son like the Father is eternal.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:346
verses.text: And so the Unborn Father and the Only-begotten Son share all the same qualities.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:347
verses.text: They are equal in years, and that very similarity between the sole-existing paternal essence and its offspring prevents distinction in any quality.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:348
verses.text: II.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:349
verses.text: "If any man says that the Father and the Son are two Gods: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:350
verses.text: III.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:351
verses.text: "And if any man says that God is one, but does not confess that Christ who is God and eternal Son of God ministered to the Father in the creation of all things: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:352
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:353
verses.text: The very statement of the name as our religion states it gives us a clear insight into the fact.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:354
verses.text: For since it is condemned to say that the Father and the Son are two Gods, and it is also accursed to deny that the Son is God, any opinion as to the substance of the one being different from that of the other in asserting two Gods is excluded.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:355
verses.text: For there is no other essence, except that of God the Father, from which God the Son of God was born before time.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:356
verses.text: For since we are compelled to confess God the Father, and roundly declare that Christ the Son of God is God, and between these two truths lies the impious confession of two Gods: They must on the ground of their identity of nature and name be one in the kind of their essence if the name of their essence is necessarily one.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:357
verses.text: IV.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:358
verses.text: "If any one dares to say that the Unborn God, or a part of Him, was born of Mary: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:359
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:360
verses.text: The fact of the essence declared to be one in the Father and the Son having one name on account of their similarity of nature seemed to offer an opportunity to heretics to declare that the Unborn God, or a part of Him, was born of Mary.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:361
verses.text: The danger was met by the wholesome resolution that he who declared this should be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:362
verses.text: For the unity of the name which religion employs and which is based on the exact similarity of their natural essence, has not repudiated the Person of the begotten essence so as to represent, under cover of the unity of name, that the substance of God is singular and undifferentiated because we predicate one name for the essence of each, that is, predicate one God, on account of the exactly similar substance of the undivided nature in each Person.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:363
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:364
verses.text: "If any man say that the Son existed before Mary only according to foreknowledge or predestination, and denies that He was born of the Father before the ages and with God, and that all things were made through Him: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:365
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:366
verses.text: While denying that the God of us all, the Son of God, existed before He was born in bodily form, some assert that He existed according to foreknowledge and predestination, and not according to the essence of a personally subsistent nature: that is, because the Father predestined the Son to have existence some day by being born of the Virgin, He was announced to us by the Father's foreknowledge rather than born and existent before the ages in the substance of the divine nature, and that all things which He Himself spake in the prophets concerning the mysteries of His incarnation and passion were simply said concerning Him by the Father according to His foreknowledge.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:367
verses.text: Consequently this perverse doctrine is condemned, so that we know that the Only-begotten Son of God was born of the Father before all worlds, and formed the worlds and all creation, and that He was not merely predestined to be born.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:368
verses.text: VI.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:369
verses.text: "If any man says that the substance of God is expanded and contracted: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:370
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:371
verses.text: To contract and expand are bodily affections: but God who is a Spirit and breathes where He listeth, does not expand or contract Himself through any change of substance.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:372
verses.text: Remaining free and outside the bond of any bodily nature, He supplies out of Himself what He wills, when He wills, and where He wills.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:373
verses.text: Therefore it is impious to ascribe any change of substance to such an unfettered Power.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:374
verses.text: VII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:375
verses.text: "If any man says that the expanded substance of God makes the Son, or names Son His expanded substance: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:376
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:377
verses.text: The above opinion, although meant to teach the immutability of God, yet prepared the way for the following heresy.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:378
verses.text: Some have ventured to say that the Unborn God by expansion of His substance extended Himself as far as the holy Virgin, in order that this extension produced by the increase of His nature and assuming manhood might be called Son.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:379
verses.text: They denied that the Son who is perfect God born before time began was the same as He who was afterwards born as Man.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:380
verses.text: Therefore the Catholic Faith condemns all denial of the immutability of the Father and of the birth of the Son.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:381
verses.text: VIII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:382
verses.text: "If any man says that the Son is the internal or uttered Word of God: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:383
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:384
verses.text: Heretics, destroying as far as in them lies the Son of God, confess Him to be only the word, going forth as an utterance from the speaker's lips and the unembodied sound of an impersonal voice: so that God the Father has as Son a word resembling any word we utter in virtue of our inborn power of speaking.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:385
verses.text: Therefore this dangerous deceit is condemned, which asserts that God the Word, who was in the beginning with God, is only the word of a voice sometimes internal and sometimes expressed.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:386
verses.text: IX.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:387
verses.text: "If any man says that the man alone born of Mary is the Son: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:388
verses.text: We cannot declare that the Son of God is born of Mary without declaring Him to be both Man and God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:389
verses.text: But lest the declaration that He is both God and Man should give occasion to deceit, the Council immediately adds,  X.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:390
verses.text: "If any man though saying that God and Man was born of Mary, understands thereby the Unborn God: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:391
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:392
verses.text: Thus is preserved both the name and power of the divine substance.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:393
verses.text: For since he is anathema who says that the Son of God by Mary is man and not God; and he falls under the same condemnation who says that the Unborn God became man: God made Man is not denied to be God but denied to be the Unborn God, the Father being distinguished from the Son not under the head of nature or by diversity of substance, but only by such pre-eminence as His birthless nature gives.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:394
verses.text: XI.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:395
verses.text: "If any man hearing The Word was made Flesh thinks that the Word was transformed into Flesh, or says that He suffered change in taking Flesh: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:396
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:397
verses.text: This preserves the dignity of the Godhead: so that in the fact that the Word was made Flesh, the Word, in becoming Flesh, has not lost through being Flesh what constituted the Word, nor has become transformed into Flesh, so as to cease to be the Word; but the Word was made Flesh in order that the Flesh might begin to be what the Word is.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:398
verses.text: Else whence came to His Flesh miraculous power in working, glory on the Mount, knowledge of the thoughts of human hearts, calmness in His passion, life in His death? God knowing no change, when made Flesh lost nothing of the prerogatives of His substance.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:399
verses.text: XII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:400
verses.text: "If any man hearing that the only Son of God was crucified, says that His divinity suffered corruption or pain or change or diminution or destruction: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:401
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:402
verses.text: It is clearly shewn why the Word, though He was made Flesh, was nevertheless not transformed into Flesh.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:403
verses.text: Though these kinds of suffering affect the infirmity of the flesh, yet God the Word when made Flesh could not change under suffering.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:404
verses.text: Suffering and change are not identical.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:405
verses.text: Suffering of every kind causes all flesh to change through sensitiveness and endurance of pain.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:406
verses.text: But the Word that was made Flesh, although He made Himself subject to suffering, was nevertheless unchanged by the liability to suffer.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:407
verses.text: For He was able to suffer, and yet the Word was not possible.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:408
verses.text: Possibility denotes a nature that is weak; but suffering in itself is the endurance of pains inflicted, and since the Godhead is immutable and yet the Word was made Flesh, such pains found in Him a material which they could affect though the Person of the Word had no infirmity or possibility.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:409
verses.text: And so when He suffered His Nature remained immutable because like His Father, His Person is of an impassible essence, though it is born.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:410
verses.text: XIII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:411
verses.text: "If any man says Let us make manwas not spoken by the Father to the Son, but by God to Himself: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:412
verses.text: XIV.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:413
verses.text: "If any man says that the Son did not appear to Abraham, but the Unborn God, or a part of Him: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:414
verses.text: XV.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:415
verses.text: "If any man says that the Son did not wrestle with Jacob as a man, but the Unborn God, or a part of Him: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:416
verses.text: XVI.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:417
verses.text: "If any man does not understand The Lord rained from the Lord to be spoken of the Father and the Son, but says that the Father rained from Himself: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:418
verses.text: For the Lord the Son rained from the Lord the Father".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:419
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:420
verses.text: These points had to be inserted into the creed because Photinus, against whom the synod was held, denied them.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:421
verses.text: They were inserted lest any one should dare to assert that the Son of God did not exist before the Son of the Virgin, and should attach to the Unborn God with the foolish perversity of an insane heresy all the above passages which refer to the Son of God, and while applying them to the Father, deny the Person of the Son.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:422
verses.text: The clearness of these statements absolves us from the necessity of interpreting them.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:423
verses.text: XVII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:424
verses.text: "If any man says that the Lord and the Lord, the Father and the Son, are two Gods because of the aforesaid words: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:425
verses.text: For we do not make the Son the equal or peer of the Father, but understand the Son to be subject.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:426
verses.text: For He did not come down to Sodom without the Father's will, nor rain from Himself but from the Lord, to wit, by the Father's authority; nor does He sit at the Father's right hand by His own authority, but because He hears the Father saying, Sit Thou on My right hand".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:427
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:428
verses.text: The foregoing and the following statements utterly remove any ground for suspecting that this definition asserts a diversity of different deities in the Lord and the Lord.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:429
verses.text: No comparison is made because it was seen to be impious to say that there are two Gods: not that they refrain from making the Son equal and peer of the Father in order to deny that He is God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:430
verses.text: For, since he is anathema who denies that Christ is God, it is not on that score that it is profane to speak of two equal Gods.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:431
verses.text: God is One on account of the true character of His natural essence and because from the Unborn God the Father, who is the one God, the Only-begotten God the Son is born, and draws His divine Being only from God; and since the essence of Him who is begotten is exactly similar to the essence of Him who begot Him, there must be one name for the exactly similar nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:432
verses.text: That the Son is not on a level with the Father and is not equal to Him is chiefly shewn in the fact that He was subjected to Him to render obedience, in that the Lord rained from the Lord and that the Father did not, as Photinus and Sabellius say, rain from Himself, as the Lord from the Lord; in that He then sat down at the right hand of God when it was told Him to seat Himself; in that He is sent, in that He receives, in that He submits in all things to the will of Him who sent Him.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:433
verses.text: But the subordination of filial love is not a diminution of essence, nor does pious duty cause a degeneration of nature, since in spite of the fact that both the Unborn Father is God and the Only-begotten Son of God is God, God is nevertheless One, and the subjection and dignity of the Son are both taught in that by being called Son He is made subject to that name which because it implies that God is His Father is yet a name which denotes His nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:434
verses.text: Having a name which belongs to Him whose Son He is, He is subject to the Father both in service and name; yet in such a way that the subordination of His name bears witness to the true character of His natural and exactly similar essence.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:435
verses.text: XVIII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:436
verses.text: "If any man says that the Father and the Son are one Person: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:437
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:438
verses.text: Sheer perversity calls for no contradiction: and yet the mad frenzy of certain men has been so violent as to dare to predicate one Person with two names.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:439
verses.text: XIX.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:440
verses.text: "If any man speaking of the Holy Ghost the Paraclete say that He is the Unborn God: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:441
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:442
verses.text: The further clause makes liable to anathema the predicating Unborn God of the Paraclete.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:443
verses.text: For it is most impious to say that He who was sent by the Son for our consolation is the Unborn God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:444
verses.text: XX.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:445
verses.text: "If any man deny that, as the Lord has taught us, the Paraclete is different from the Son; for He said, And the Further shall send you another Comforter, whom I shall ask: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:446
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:447
verses.text: We remember that the Paraclete was sent by the Son, and at the beginning the creed explained this.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:448
verses.text: But since through the virtue of His nature, which is exactly similar, the Son has frequently called His own works the works of the Father, saying, I do the works of My Father: so when He intended to send the Paraclete, as He often promised, He said sometimes that He was to be sent from the Father, in that He was piously wont to refer all that He did to the Father.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:449
verses.text: And from this the heretics often seize an opportunity of saying that the Son Himself is the Paraclete: while by the fact that He promised to pray that another Comforter should be sent from the Father, He shews the difference between Him who is sent and Him who asked.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:450
verses.text: XXI.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:451
verses.text: "If any man says that the Holy Spirit is a part of the Father or of the Son: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:452
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:453
verses.text: The insane frenzy of the heretics, and not any genuine difficulty, rendered it necessary that this should be written.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:454
verses.text: For since the name of Holy Spirit has its own signification, and the Holy Spirit the Paraclete has the office and rank peculiar to His Person, and since the Father and the Son are everywhere declared to be immutable: how could the Holy Spirit be asserted to be a part either of the Father or of the Son? But since this folly is often affirmed amid other follies by godless men, it was needful that the pious should condemn it.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:455
verses.text: XXII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:456
verses.text: "If any man says that the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit are three Gods: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:457
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:458
verses.text: Since it is contrary to religion to say that there are two Gods, because we remember and declare that nowhere has it been affirmed that there is more than one God: how much more worthy of condemnation is it to name three Gods in the Father, Son, and Holy Ghost? Nevertheless, since heretics say this, Catholics rightly condemn it.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:459
verses.text: XXIII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:460
verses.text: "If any man, after the example of the Jews, understand as said for the destruction of the Eternal Only-begotten God, the words, I am the first God, and I am the last God, and beside Me there is no God, which were spoken for the destruction of idols and them that are no gods: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:461
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:462
verses.text: Though we condemn a plurality of gods and declare that God is only one, we cannot deny that the Son of God is God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:463
verses.text: Nay, the true character of His nature causes the name that is denied to a plurality to be the privilege of His essence.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:464
verses.text: The words, Beside Me there is no God, cannot rob the Son of His divinity: because beside Him who is of God there is no other God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:465
verses.text: And these words of God the Father cannot annul the divinity of Him who was born of Himself with an essence in no way different from His own nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:466
verses.text: The Jews interpret this passage as proving the bare unity of God, because they are ignorant of the Only-begotten God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:467
verses.text: But we, while we deny that there are two Gods, abhor the idea of a diversity of natural essence in the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:468
verses.text: The words, Beside Me there is no God, take away an impious belief in false gods.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:469
verses.text: In confessing that God is One, and also saying that the Son is God, our use of the same name affirms that there is no difference of substance between the two Persons.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:470
verses.text: XXIV.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:471
verses.text: "If any man says that the Son was made by the will of God, like any object in creation: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:472
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:473
verses.text: To all creatures the will of God has given substance: but a perfect birth gave to the Son a nature from a substance that is impossible and itself unborn.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:474
verses.text: All created things are such as God willed them to be: but the Son who is born of God has such a personality as God has.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:475
verses.text: God's nature did not produce a nature unlike itself: but the Son begotten of God's substance has derived the essence of His nature by virtue of His origin, not from an act of will after the manner of creatures.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:476
verses.text: XXV.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:477
verses.text: "If any man says that the Son was born against the will of the Father: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:478
verses.text: For the Father was not forced against His own will, or induced against His will by any necessity of nature, to beget His Son; but as soon as He willed, before time and without passion He begat Him of Himself and shewed Him forth".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:479
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:480
verses.text: Since it was taught that the Son did not, like all other things, owe His existence to God's will, lest He should be thought to derive His essence only at His Father's will and not in virtue of His own nature, an opportunity seemed thereby to be given to heretics to attribute to God the Father a necessity of begetting the Son from Himself, as though He had brought forth the Son by a law of nature in spite of Himself.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:481
verses.text: But such liability to be acted upon does not exist in God the Father: in the ineffable and perfect birth of the Son it was neither mere will that begat Him nor was the Father's essence changed or forced at the bidding of a natural law.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:482
verses.text: Nor was any substance sought for to beget Him, nor is the nature of the Begetter changed in the Begotten, nor is the Father's unique name affected by time.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:483
verses.text: Before all time the Father, out of the essence of His nature, with a desire that was subject to no passion, gave to the Son a birth that conveyed the essence of His nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:484
verses.text: XXVI.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:485
verses.text: "If any man says that the Son is incapable of birth and without beginning, speaking as though there were two incapable of birth and unborn and without beginning, and makes two Gods: let him be anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:486
verses.text: For the Head, which is the beginning of all things, is the Son; but the Head or beginning of Christ is God: for so to One who is without beginning and is the beginning of all things, we refer the whole world through Christ".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:487
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:488
verses.text: To declare the Son to be incapable of birth is the height of impiety.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:489
verses.text: God would no longer be One: for the nature of the one Unborn God demands that we should confess that God is one.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:490
verses.text: Since therefore God is one, there cannot be two incapable of birth: because God is one (although both the Father is God and the Son of God is God) for the very reason that incapability of birth is the only quality that can belong to one Person only.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:491
verses.text: The Son is God for the very reason that He derives His birth from that essence which cannot be born.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:492
verses.text: Therefore our holy faith rejects the idea that the Son is incapable of birth in order to predicate one God incapable of birth and consequently one God, and in order to embrace the Only-begotten nature, begotten from the unborn essence, in the one name of the Unborn God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:493
verses.text: For the Head of all things is the Son: but the Head of the Son is God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:494
verses.text: And to one God through this stepping-stone and by this confession all things are referred, since the whole world takes its beginning from Him to whom God Himself is the beginning.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:495
verses.text: XXVII.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:496
verses.text: "Once more we strengthen the understanding of Christianity by saying, If any man denies that Christ, who is God and the Son of God, existed before time began and aided the Father in the perfecting of all things; but says that only from the time that He was born of Mary did He gain the name of Christ and Son and a beginning of His deity: let him be anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:497
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:498
verses.text: A condemnation of that heresy on account of which the Synod was held necessarily concluded with an explanation of the whole faith that was being opposed.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:499
verses.text: This heresy falsely stated that the beginning of the Son of God dated from His birth of Mary.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:500
verses.text: According to evangelical and apostolic doctrine the corner-stone of our faith is that our Lord Jesus Christ, who is God and Son of God, cannot be separated from the Father in title or power or difference of substance or interval of time.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:501
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:502
verses.text: You perceive that the truth has been sought by many paths through the advice and opinions of different bishops, and the ground of their views has been set forth by the separate declarations inscribed in this creed.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:503
verses.text: Every separate point of heretical assertion has been successfully refuted.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:504
verses.text: The infinite and boundless God cannot be made comprehensible by a few words of human speech.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:505
verses.text: Brevity often misleads both learner and teacher, and a concentrated discourse either causes a subject not to be understood, or spoils the meaning of an argument where a thing is hinted at, and is not proved by full demonstration.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:506
verses.text: The bishops fully understood this, and therefore have used for the purpose of teaching many definitions and a profusion of words that the ordinary understanding might find no difficulty, but that their hearers might be saturated with the truth thus differently expressed, and that in treating of divine things these adequate and manifold definitions might leave no room for danger or obscurity.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:507
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:508
verses.text: You must not be surprised, dear brethren, that so many creeds have recently been written.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:509
verses.text: The frenzy of heretics makes it necessary.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:510
verses.text: The danger of the Eastern Churches is so great that it is rare to find either priest or layman that belongs to this faith, of the orthodoxy of which you may judge.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:511
verses.text: Certain individuals have acted so wrongly as to support the side of evil, and the strength of the wicked has been increased by the exile of some of the bishops, the cause of which you are acquainted with.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:512
verses.text: I am not speaking about distant events or writing down incidents of which I know nothing: I have heard and seen the faults which we now have to combat.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:513
verses.text: They are not laymen but bishops who are guilty.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:514
verses.text: Except the bishop Eleusius and his few comrades, the greater part of the ten provinces of Asia, in which I am now staying, really know not God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:515
verses.text: Would that they knew nothing about Him, for their ignorance would meet with a readier pardon than their detraction.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:516
verses.text: These faithful bishops do not keep silence in their pain.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:517
verses.text: They seek for the unity of that faith of which others have long since robbed them.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:518
verses.text: The necessity of a united exposition of that faith was first felt when Hosius forgot his former deeds and words, and a fresh yet festering heresy broke out at Sirmium.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:519
verses.text: Of Hosius I say nothing, I leave his conduct in the background lest man's judgment should forget what once he was.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:520
verses.text: But everywhere there are scandals, schisms and treacheries.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:521
verses.text: Hence some of those who had formerly written one creed were compelled to sign another.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:522
verses.text: I make no complaint against these long-suffering Eastern bishops, it was enough that they gave at least a compulsory assent to the faith after they had once been willing to blaspheme.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:523
verses.text: I think it a subject of congratulation that a single penitent should be found among such obstinate, blaspheming and heretical bishops.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:524
verses.text: But, brethren, you enjoy happiness and glory in the Lord, who meanwhile retain and conscientiously confess the whole apostolic faith, and have hitherto been ignorant of written creeds.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:525
verses.text: You have not needed the letter, for you abounded in the spirit.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:526
verses.text: You required not the office of a hand to write what you believed in your hearts and professed unto salvation.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:527
verses.text: It was unnecessary for you to read as bishops what you held when new-born converts.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:528
verses.text: But necessity has introduced the custom of expounding creeds and signing expositions.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:529
verses.text: Where the conscience is in danger we must use the letter.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:530
verses.text: Nor is it wrong to write what it is wholesome to confess.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:531
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:532
verses.text: Kept always from guile by the gift of the Holy Spirit, we confess and write of our own will that there are not two Gods but one God; nor do we therefore deny that the Son of God is also God; for He is God of God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:533
verses.text: We deny that there are two incapable of birth, because God is one through the prerogative of being incapable of birth; nor does it follow that the Unbegotten is not God, for His source is the Unborn substance.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:534
verses.text: There is not one subsistent Person, but a similar substance in both Persons.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:535
verses.text: There is not one name of God applied to dissimilar natures, but a wholly similar essence belonging to one name and nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:536
verses.text: One is not superior to the other on account of the kind of His substance, but one is subject to the other because born of the other.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:537
verses.text: The Father is greater because He is Father, the Son is not the less because He is Son.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:538
verses.text: The difference is one of the meaning of a name and not of a nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:539
verses.text: We confess that the Father is not affected by time, but do not deny that the Son is equally eternal.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:540
verses.text: We assert that the Father is in the Son because the Son has nothing in Himself unlike the Father: we confess that the Son is in the Father because the existence of the Son is not from any other source.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:541
verses.text: We recognize that their nature is mutual and similar because equal: we do not think them to be one Person because they are one: we declare that they are through the similarity of an identical nature one, in such a way that they nevertheless are not one Person.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:542
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:543
verses.text: I have expounded, beloved brethren, my belief in our common faith so far as our wonted human speech permitted and the Lord, whom I have ever besought, as He is my witness, has given me power.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:544
verses.text: If I have said too little, nay, if I have said almost nothing, I ask you to remember that it is not belief but words that are lacking.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:545
verses.text: Perhaps I shall thereby prove that my human nature, though not my will, is weak: and I pardon my human nature if it cannot speak as it would of God, for it is enough for its salvation to have believed the things of God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:546
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:547
verses.text: Since your faith and mine, so far as I am conscious, is in no danger before God, and I have shewn you, as you wished, the creeds that have been set forth by the Eastern bishops (though I repeat that they were few in number, for, considering how numerous the Eastern Churches are, that faith is held by few), I have also declared my own convictions about divine things, according to the doctrine of the apostles.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:548
verses.text: It remains for you to investigate without suspicion the points that mislead the unguarded temper of our simple minds, for there is now no opportunity left of hearing.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:549
verses.text: And although I shall no longer fear that sentence will not be passed upon me in accordance with the whole exposition of the creed, I ask you to allow me to express a wish that I may not have the sentence passed until the exposition is actually completed.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:550
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:551
verses.text: Many of us, beloved brethren, declare the substance of the Father and the Son to be one in such a spirit that I consider the statement to be quite as much wrong as right.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:552
verses.text: The expression contains both a conscientious conviction and the opportunity for delusion.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:553
verses.text: If we assert the one substance, understanding it to mean the likeness of natural qualities and such a likeness as includes not only the species but the genus, we assert it in a truly religious spirit, provided we believe that the one substance signifies such a similitude of qualities that the unity is not the unity of a monad but of equals.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:554
verses.text: By equality I mean exact similarity so that the likeness may be called an equality, provided that the equality imply unity because it implies an equal pair, and that the unity which implies an equal pair be not wrested to mean a single Person.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:555
verses.text: Therefore the one substance will be asserted piously if it does not abolish the subsistent personality or divide the one substance into two, for their substance by the true character of the Son's birth and by their natural likeness is so free from difference that it is called one.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:556
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:557
verses.text: But if we attribute one substance to the Father and the Son to teach that there is a solitary personal existence although denoted by two titles: then though we confess the Son with our lips we do not keep Him in our hearts, since in confessing one substance we then really say that the Father and the Son constitute one undifferentiated Person.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:558
verses.text: Nay, there immediately arises an opportunity for the erroneous belief that the Father is divided, and that He cut off a portion of Himself to be His Son.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:559
verses.text: That is what the heretics mean when they say the substance is one: and the terminology of our good confession so gratifies them that it aids heresy when the word ὁμοούσιος is left by itself, undefined and ambiguous.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:560
verses.text: There is also a third error.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:561
verses.text: When the Father and the Son are said to be of one substance this is thought to imply a prior substance, which the two equal Persons both possess.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:562
verses.text: Consequently the word implies three things, one original substance and two Persons, who are as it were fellow-heirs of this one substance.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:563
verses.text: For as two fellow-heirs are two, and the heritage of which they are fellow-heirs is anterior to them, so the two equal Persons might appear to be sharers in one anterior substance.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:564
verses.text: The assertion of the one substance of the Father and the Son signifies either that there is one Person who has two titles, or one divided substance that has made two imperfect substances, or that there is a third prior substance which has been usurped and assumed by two and which is called one because it was one before it was severed into two.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:565
verses.text: Where then is there room for the Son's birth? Where is the Father or the Son, if these names are explained not by the birth of the divine nature but a severing or sharing of one anterior substance?  69.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:566
verses.text: Therefore amid the numerous dangers which threaten the faith, brevity of words must be employed sparingly, lest what is piously meant be thought to be impiously expressed, and a word be judged guilty of occasioning heresy when it has been used in conscientious and unsuspecting innocence.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:567
verses.text: A Catholic about to state that the substance of the Father and the Son is one, must not begin at that point: nor hold this word all important as though true faith did not exist where the word was not used.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:568
verses.text: He will be safe in asserting the one substance if he has first said that the Father is unbegotten, that the Son is born, that He draws His personal subsistence from the Father, that He is like the Father in might, honour and nature, that He is subject to the Father as to the Author of His being, that He did not commit robbery by making Himself equal with God, in whose form He remained, that He was obedient unto death.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:569
verses.text: He did not spring from nothing, but was born.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:570
verses.text: He is not incapable of birth but equally eternal.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:571
verses.text: He is not the Father, but the Son begotten of Him.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:572
verses.text: He is not any portion of God, but is whole God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:573
verses.text: He is not Himself the source but the image; the image of God born of God to be God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:574
verses.text: He is not a creature but is God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:575
verses.text: Not another God in the kind of His substance, but the one God in virtue of the essence of His exactly similar substance.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:576
verses.text: God is not one in Person but in nature, for the Born and the Begetter have nothing different or unlike.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:577
verses.text: After saying all this, he does not err in declaring one substance of the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:578
verses.text: Nay, if he now denies the one substance he sins.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:579
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:580
verses.text: Therefore let no one think that our words were meant to deny the one substance.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:581
verses.text: We are giving the very reason why it should not be denied.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:582
verses.text: Let no one think that the word ought to be used by itself and unexplained.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:583
verses.text: Otherwise the word ὁμοούσιος is not used in a religious spirit.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:584
verses.text: I will not endure to hear that Christ was born of Mary unless I also hear, In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:585
verses.text: I will not hear Christ was hungry, unless I hear that after His fast of forty days He said, Man doth not live by bread alone.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:586
verses.text: I will not hear He thirsted unless I also hear Whosoever drinketh of the water that I shall give him shall never thirst.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:587
verses.text: I will not hear Christ suffered unless I hear, The hour is come that the Son of man should be glorified.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:588
verses.text: I will not hear He died unless I hear He rose again.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:589
verses.text: Let us bring forward no isolated point of the divine mysteries to rouse the suspicions of our hearers and give an occasion to the blasphemers.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:590
verses.text: We must first preach the birth and subordination of the Son and the likeness of His nature, and then we may preach in godly fashion that the Father and the Son are of one substance.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:591
verses.text: I do not personally understand why we ought to preach before everything else, as the most valuable and important of doctrines and in itself sufficient, a truth which cannot be piously preached before other truths, although it is impious to deny it after them.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:592
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:593
verses.text: Beloved brethren, we must not deny that there is one substance of the Father and the Son, but we must not declare it without giving our reasons.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:594
verses.text: The one substance must be derived from the true character of the begotten nature, not from any division, any confusion of Persons, any sharing of an anterior substance.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:595
verses.text: It may be right to assert the one substance, it may be right to keep silence about it.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:596
verses.text: You believe in the birth and you believe in the likeness.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:597
verses.text: Why should the word cause mutual suspicions, when we view the fact in the same way? Let us believe and say that there is one substance, but in virtue of the true character of the nature and not to imply a blasphemous unity of Persons.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:598
verses.text: Let the oneness be due to the fact that there are similar Persons and not a solitary Person.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:599
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:600
verses.text: But perhaps the word similarity may not seem fully appropriate.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:601
verses.text: If so, I ask how I can express the equality of one Person with the other except by such a word? Or is to be like not the same thing as to be equal? If I say the divine nature is one I am suspected of meaning that it is undifferentiated: if I say the Persons are similar, I mean that I compare what is exactly like.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:602
verses.text: I ask what position equal holds between like and one? I enquire whether it means similarity rather than singularity.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:603
verses.text: Equality does not exist between things unlike, nor does similarity exist in one.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:604
verses.text: What is the difference between those that are similar and those that are equal? Can one equal be distinguished from the other? So those who are equal are not unlike.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:605
verses.text: If then those who are unlike are not equals, what can those who are like be but equals?  73.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:606
verses.text: Therefore, beloved brethren, in declaring that the Son is like in all things to the Father, we declare nothing else than that He is equal.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:607
verses.text: Likeness means perfect equality, and this fact we may gather from the Holy Scriptures, And Adam lived two hundred and thirty years, and begat a son according to his own image and according to his own likeness; and called his name Seth.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:608
verses.text: I ask what was the nature of his likeness and image which Adam begot in Seth? Remove bodily infirmities, remove the first stage of conception, remove birth-pangs, and every kind of human need.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:609
verses.text: I ask whether this likeness which exists in Seth differs in nature from the author of his being, or whether there was in each an essence of a different kind, so that Seth had not at his birth the natural essence of Adam? Nay, he had a likeness to Adam, even though we deny it, for his nature was not different.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:610
verses.text: This likeness of nature in Seth was not due to a nature of a different kind, since Seth was begotten from only one father, so we see that a likeness of nature renders things equal because this likeness betokens an exactly similar essence.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:611
verses.text: Therefore every son by virtue of his natural birth is the equal of his father, in that he has a natural likeness to him.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:612
verses.text: And with regard to the nature of the Father and the Son the blessed John teaches the very likeness which Moses says existed between Seth and Adam, a likeness which is this equality of nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:613
verses.text: He says, Therefore the Jews sought the more to kill Him, because He not only had broken the Sabbath, but said also that God was His father, making Himself equal with God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:614
verses.text: Why do we allow minds that are dulled with the weight of sin to interfere with the doctrines and sayings of such holy men, and impiously match our rash though sluggish senses against their impregnable assertions? According to Moses, Seth is the likeness of Adam, according to John, the Son is equal to the Father, yet we seek to find a third impossible something between the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:615
verses.text: He is like the Father, He is the Son of the Father, He is born of Him: this fact alone justifies the assertion that they are one.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:616
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:617
verses.text: I am aware, dear brethren, that there are some who confess the likeness, but deny the equality.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:618
verses.text: Let them speak as they will, and insert the poison of their blasphemy into ignorant ears.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:619
verses.text: If they say that there is a difference between likeness and equality, I ask whence equality can be obtained? If the Son is like the Father in essence, might, glory and eternity, I ask why they decline to say He is equal? In the above creed an anathema was pronounced on any man who should say that the Father was Father of an essence unlike Himself.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:620
verses.text: Therefore if He gave to Him whom He begat without effect upon Himself a nature which was neither another nor a different nature, He cannot have given Him any other than His own.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:621
verses.text: Likeness then is the sharing of what is one's own, the sharing of one's own is equality, and equality admits of no difference.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:622
verses.text: Those things which do not differ at all are one.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:623
verses.text: So the Father and the Son are one, not by unity of Person but by equality of nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:624
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:625
verses.text: Although general conviction and divine authority sanction no difference between likeness and equality, since both Moses and John would lead us to believe the Son is like the Father and also His equal, yet let us consider whether the Lord, when the Jews were angry with Him for calling God His Father and thus making Himself equal with God, did Himself teach that He was equal with God.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:626
verses.text: He says, The Son can do nothing of Himself, but what He seeth the Father do.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:627
verses.text: He shewed that the Father originates by saying Can do nothing of Himself, He calls attention to His own obedience by adding, but what He seeth the Father do.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:628
verses.text: There is no difference of might, He says He can do nothing that He does not see because it is His nature and not His sight that gives Him power.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:629
verses.text: But His obedience consists in His being able only when He sees.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:630
verses.text: And so by the fact that He has power when He sees, He shews that He does not gain power by seeing but claims power on the authority of seeing.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:631
verses.text: The natural might does not differ in Father and Son, the Son's equality of power with the Father not being due to any increase or advance of the Son's nature but to the Father's example.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:632
verses.text: In short that honour which the Son's subjection retained for the Father belongs equally to the Son on the strength of His nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:633
verses.text: He has Himself added, What things soever He doeth, these also doeth the Son likewise.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:634
verses.text: Surely then the likeness implies equality.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:635
verses.text: Certainly it does, even though we deny it: for these also doeth the Son likewise.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:636
verses.text: Are not things done likewise the same? Or do not the same things admit equality? Is there any other difference between likeness and equality, when things that are done likewise are understood to be made the same? Unless perchance any one will deny that the same things are equal, or deny that similar things are equal, for things that are done in like manner are not only declared to be equal but to be the same things.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:637
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:638
verses.text: Therefore, brethren, likeness of nature can be attacked by no cavil, and the Son cannot be said to lack the true qualities of the Father's nature because He is like Him.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:639
verses.text: No real likeness exists where there is no equality of nature, and equality of nature cannot exist unless it imply unity, not unity of person but of kind.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:640
verses.text: It is right to believe, religious to feel, and wholesome to confess, that we do not deny that the substance of the Father and the Son is one because it is similar, and that it is similar because they are one.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:641
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:642
