verses.text: Beloved, after explaining in a faithful and godly manner the meaning of the phrases one substance, in Greek ὁμοούσιον, and similar substance or ὁμοιούσιον, and shewing very completely the faults which may arise from a deceitful brevity or dangerous simplicity of language, it only remains for me to address myself to the holy bishops of the East.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:643
verses.text: We have no longer any mutual suspicions about our faith, and those which before now have been due to mere misunderstanding are being cleared away.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:644
verses.text: They will pardon me if I proceed to speak somewhat freely with them on the basis of our common faith.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:645
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:646
verses.text: Ye who have begun to be eager for apostolic and evangelical doctrine, kindled by the fire of faith amid the thick darkness of a night of heresy, with how great a hope of recalling the true faith have you inspired us by consistently checking the bold attack of infidelity! In former days it was only in obscure corners that our Lord Jesus Christ was denied to be the Son of God according to His nature, and was asserted to have no share in the Father's essence, but like the creatures to have received His origin from things that were not.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:647
verses.text: But the heresy now bursts forth backed by civil authority, and what it once muttered in secret it has of late boasted of in open triumph.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:648
verses.text: Whereas in former times it has tried by secret mines to creep into the Catholic Church, it has now put forth every power of this world in the fawning manners of a false religion.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:649
verses.text: For the perversity of these men has been so audacious that when they dared not preach this doctrine publicly themselves, they beguiled the Emperor to give them hearing.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:650
verses.text: For they did beguile an ignorant sovereign so successfully that though he was busy with war he expounded their infidel creed, and before he was regenerate by baptism imposed a form of faith upon the churches.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:651
verses.text: Opposing bishops they drove into exile.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:652
verses.text: They drove me also to wish for exile, by trying to force me to commit blasphemy.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:653
verses.text: May I always be an exile, if only the truth begins to be preached again! I thank God that the Emperor, through your warnings, acknowledged his ignorance, and through these your definitions of faith came to recognize an error which was not his own but that of his advisers.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:654
verses.text: He freed himself from the reproach of impiety in the eyes of God and men, when he respectfully received your embassy, and after you had won from him a confession of his ignorance, shewed his knowledge of the hypocrisy of the men whose influence brought him under this reproach.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:655
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:656
verses.text: These are deceivers, I both fear and believe they are deceivers, beloved brethren; for they have ever deceived.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:657
verses.text: This very document is marked by hypocrisy.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:658
verses.text: They excuse themselves for having desired silence as to ὁμοούσιον and ὁμοιούσιον on the ground that they taught that the meaning of the words was identical.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:659
verses.text: Rustic bishops, I trow, and untutored in the significance of ὁμοοίσιον: as though there had never been any Council about the matter, or any dispute.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:660
verses.text: But suppose they did not know what ὁμοούσιον was, or were really unaware that ὁμοιούσιον meant of a like essence.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:661
verses.text: Granted that they were ignorant of this, why did they wish to be ignorant of the generation of the Son? If it cannot be expressed in words, is it therefore unknowable? But if we cannot know how He was born, can we refuse to know even this, that God the Son being born not of another substance but of God, has not an essence differing from the Father's? Have they not read that the Son is to be honoured even as the Father, that they prefer the Father in honour? Were they ignorant that the Father is seen in the Son, that they make the Son differ in dignity, splendour and majesty? Is this due to ignorance that the Son, like all other things, is made subject to the Father, and while thus subjected is not distinguished from them? A distinction does exist, for the subjection of the Son is filial reverence, the subjection of all other things is the weakness of things created.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:662
verses.text: They knew that He suffered, but when, may I ask, did they come to know that He jointly suffered? They avoid the words ὁμοούσιον and ὁμοιούσιον, because they are not in Scripture: I enquire whence they gathered that the Son jointly suffered? Can they mean that there were two Persons who suffered? This is what the word leads us to believe.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:663
verses.text: What of those words, Jesus Christ the Son of God? Is Jesus Christ one, and the Son of God another? If the Son of God is not one and the same inwardly and outwardly, if ignorance on such a point is permissible, then believe that they were ignorant of the meaning of ὁμοούσιον.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:664
verses.text: But if on these points ignorance leads to blasphemy and yet cannot find even a false excuse, I fear that they lied in professing ignorance of the word ὁμοιούσιον.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:665
verses.text: I do not greatly complain of the pardon you extended them; it is reverent to reserve for God His own prerogatives, and mistakes of ignorance are but human.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:666
verses.text: But the two bishops, Ursacius and Valens, must pardon me for not believing that at their age and with their experience they were really ignorant.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:667
verses.text: It is very difficult not to think they are lying, seeing that it is only by a falsehood that they can clear themselves on another score.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:668
verses.text: But God rather grant that I am mistaken than that they really knew.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:669
verses.text: For I had rather be judged in the wrong than that your faith should be contaminated by communion with the guilt of heresy.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:670
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:671
verses.text: Now I beseech you, holy brethren, to listen to my anxieties with indulgence.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:672
verses.text: The Lord is my witness that in no matter do I wish to criticise the definitions of your faith, which you brought to Sirmium.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:673
verses.text: But forgive me if I do not understand certain points; I will comfort myself with the recollection that the spirits of the prophets are subject to the prophets.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:674
verses.text: Perhaps I am not presumptuous in gathering from this that I too may understand something that another does not know.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:675
verses.text: Not that I have dared to hint that you are ignorant of anything according to the measure of knowledge: but for the unity of the Catholic faith suffer me to be as anxious as yourselves.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:676
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:677
verses.text: Your letter on the meaning of ὁμοούσιον and ὁμοιούσιον, which Valens, Ursacius and Germinius demanded should be read at Sirmium, I understand to have been on certain points no less cautious than outspoken.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:678
verses.text: And with regard to ὁμοούσιον and ὁμοιούσιον your proof has left no difficulty untouched.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:679
verses.text: As to the latter, which implies the similarity of essence, our opinions are the same.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:680
verses.text: But in dealing with the ὁμοούσιον, or the one essence, you declared that it ought to be rejected because the use of this word led to the idea that there was a prior substance which two Persons had divided between themselves.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:681
verses.text: I see the flaw in that way of taking it.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:682
verses.text: Any such sense is profane, and must be rejected by the Church's common decision.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:683
verses.text: The second reason that you added was that our fathers, when Paul of Samosata was pronounced a heretic, also rejected the word ὁμοούσιον, on the ground that by attributing this title to God he had taught that He was single and undifferentiated, and at once Father and to Himself.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:684
verses.text: Wherefore the Church still regards it as most profane to exclude the different personal qualities, and, under the mask of the aforesaid expressions, to revive the error of confounding the Persons and denying the personal distinctions in the Godhead.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:685
verses.text: Thirdly you mentioned this reason for disapproving of the ὁμοούσιον that in the Council of Nicaea our fathers were compelled to adopt the word on account of those who said the Son was a creature: although it ought not to be accepted, because it is not to be found in Scripture.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:686
verses.text: Your saying this causes me some astonishment.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:687
verses.text: For if the word ὁμοούσιον must be repudiated on account of its novelty, I am afraid that the word ὁμοιούσιον which is equally absent in Scripture, is in some danger.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:688
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:689
verses.text: But I am not needlessly critical on this point.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:690
verses.text: For I had rather use an expression that is new than commit sin by rejecting it.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:691
verses.text: So, then, we will pass by this question of innovation, and see whether the real question is not reduced to something which all our fellow-Christians unanimously condemn.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:692
verses.text: What man in his senses will ever declare that there is a third substance, which is common to both the Father and the Son? And who that has been reborn in Christ and confessed both the Son and the Father will follow him of Samosata in confessing that Christ is Himself to Himself both Father and Son? So in condemning the blasphemies of the heretics we hold the same opinion, and such an interpretation of ὁμοούσιον we not only reject but hate.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:693
verses.text: The question of an erroneous interpretation is at an end, when we agree in condemning the error.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:694
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:695
verses.text: But when I at last turn to speak on the third point, I pray you to let there be no conflict of suspicions where there is peace at heart.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:696
verses.text: Do not think I would advance anything hurtful to the progress of unity.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:697
verses.text: For it is absurd to fear cavil about a word when the fact expressed by the word presents no difficulty.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:698
verses.text: Who objects to the fact that the Council of Nicaea adopted the word ὁμοούσιον́̈ He who does so, must necessarily like its rejection by the Arians.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:699
verses.text: The Arians rejected the word, that God the Son might not be asserted to be born of the substance of God the Father, but formed out of nothing, like the creatures.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:700
verses.text: This is no new thing that I speak of.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:701
verses.text: The perfidy of the Arians is to be found in many of their letters and is its own witness.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:702
verses.text: If the godlessness of the negation then gave a godly meaning to the assertion, I ask why we should now criticise a word which was then rightly adopted because it was wrongly denied? If it was rightly adopted, why after supporting the right should that which extinguished the wrong be called to account? Having been used as the instrument of evil it came to be the instrument of good.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:703
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:704
verses.text: Let us see, therefore, what the Council of Nicaea intended by saying ὁμοούσιον, that is, of one substance: not certainly to hatch the heresy which arises from an erroneous interpretation of ὁμοούσιον.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:705
verses.text: I do not think the Council says that the Father and the Son divided and shared a previously existing substance to make it their own.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:706
verses.text: It will not be adverse to religion to insert in our argument the creed which was then composed to preserve religion.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:707
verses.text: "We believe in one God the Father Almighty, Maker of all things visible and invisible:  "And in one our Lord Jesus Christ, the Son of God, born of the Father, Only-begotten, that is, of the substance of the Father, God of God, Light of Light, Very God of very God, born not made, of one substance with the Father (which in Greek they call ὁμοοίσιον); By whom all things were made which are in heaven and in earth, Who for our salvation came down, And was incarnate, And was made man, And suffered, And rose again the third day, And ascended into heaven, And shall come to judge the quick and the dead.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:708
verses.text: "And in the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:709
verses.text: "But those who say, There was when He was not, And before He was born He was not, And that He was made of things that existed not, or of another substance and essence, saying that God was able to change and alter, to these the Catholic Church says anathema".

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:710
verses.text: Here the Holy Council of religious men introduces no prior substance divided between two Persons, but the Son born of the substance of the Father.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:711
verses.text: Do we, too, deny or confess anything else? And after other explanations of our common faith, it says, Born not made, of one substance with the Father (which in Greek they call ὁμοούσιον).

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:712
verses.text: What occasion is there here for an erroneous interpretation? The Son is declared to be born of the substance of the Father, not made: lest while the word born implies His divinity, the word made should imply He is a creature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:713
verses.text: For the same reason we have of one substance, not to teach that there is one solitary divine Person, but that the Son is born of the substance of God and subsists from no other source, nor in any diversity caused by a difference of substance.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:714
verses.text: Surely again this is our faith, that He subsists from no other source, and He is not unlike the Father.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:715
verses.text: Is not the meaning here of the word ὁμοούσιον that the Son is produced of the Father's nature, the essence of the Son having no other origin, and that both, therefore, have one unvarying essence? As the Son's essence has no other origin, we may rightly believe that both are of one essence, since the Son could be born with no substance but that derived from the Father's nature which was its source.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:716
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:717
verses.text: But perhaps on the opposite side it will be said that it ought to meet with disapproval, because an erroneous interpretation is generally put upon it.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:718
verses.text: If such is our fear, we ought to erase the words of the Apostle, There is one Mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus, because Photinus uses this to support his heresy, and refuse to read it because he interprets it mischievously.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:719
verses.text: And the fire or the sponge should annihilate the Epistle to the Philippians, lest Marcion should read again in it, And was found in fashion as a man, and say Christ's body was only a phantasm and not a body.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:720
verses.text: Away with the Gospel of John, lest Sabellius learn from it, I and the Father are one.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:721
verses.text: Nor must those who now affirm the Son to be a creature find it written, The Father is greater than I.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:722
verses.text: Nor must those who wish to declare that the Son is unlike the Father read: But of that day and hour knoweth no man, no, not the angels which are in heaven, neither the Son, but the Father.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:723
verses.text: We must dispense, too, with the books of Moses, lest the darkness be thought coeval with God who dwells in the unborn light, since in Genesis the day began to be after the night; lest the years of Methuselah extend later than the date of the deluge, and consequently more than eight souls were saved; lest God hearing the cry of Sodom when the measure of its sins was full should come down as though ignorant of the cry to see if the measure of its sins was full according to the cry, and be found to be ignorant of what He knew; lest any one of those who buried Moses should have known his sepulchre when he was buried; lest these passages, as the heretics think, should prove that the contradictions of the law make it its own enemy.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:724
verses.text: So as they do not understand them, we ought not to read them.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:725
verses.text: And though I should not have said it myself unless forced by the argument, we must, if it seems fit, abolish all the divine and holy Gospels with their message of our salvation, lest their statements be found inconsistent; lest we should read that the Lord who was to send the Holy Spirit was Himself born of the Holy Spirit; lest He who was to threaten death by the sword to those who should take the sword, should before His passion command that a sword should be brought; lest He who was about to descend into hell should say that He would be in paradise with the thief; lest finally the Apostles should be found at fault, in that when commanded to baptize in the name of the Father, and the Son, and the Holy Ghost, they baptized in the name of Jesus only.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:726
verses.text: I speak to you, brethren, to you, who are no longer nourished with milk, but with meat, and are strong.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:727
verses.text: Shall we, because the wise men of the world have not understood these things, and they are foolish unto them, be wise as the world is wise and believe these things foolish? Because they are hidden from the godless, shall we refuse to shine with the truth of a doctrine which we understand? We prejudice the cause of divine doctrines when we think that they ought not to exist, because some do not regard them as holy.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:728
verses.text: If so, we must not glory in the cross of Christ, because it is a stumbling-block to the world; and we must not preach death in connection with the living God, lest the godless argue that God is dead.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:729
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:730
verses.text: Some misunderstand ὁμοούσιον; does that prevent me from understanding it? The Samosatene was wrong in using the word ὁμοούσιον; does that make the Arians right in denying it? Eighty bishops once rejected it; but three hundred and eighteen recently accepted it.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:731
verses.text: And for my own part I think the number sacred, for with such a number Abraham overcame the wicked kings, and was blessed by Him who is a type of the eternal priesthood.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:732
verses.text: The former disapproved of it to oppose a heretic: the latter surely approved of it to oppose a heretic.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:733
verses.text: The authority of the fathers is weighty, is the sanctity of their successors trivial? If their opinions were contradictory, we ought to decide which is the better: but if both their approval and disapproval established the same fact, why do we carp at such good decisions?  87.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:734
verses.text: But perhaps you will reply, 'Some of those who were then present at Nicaea have now decreed that we ought to keep silence about the word ὁμοούσιον.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:735
verses.text: ' Against my will I must answer: Do not the very same men rule that we must keep silence about the word ὁμοιούσιον? I beseech you that there may be found no one of them but Hosius, that old man who loves a peaceful grave too well, who shall be found to think that we ought to keep silence about both.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:736
verses.text: Amid the fury of the heretics into what straits shall we fall at last, if while we do not accept both, we keep neither? For there seems to be no impiety in saying that since neither is found in Scripture, we ought to confess neither or both.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:737
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:738
verses.text: Holy brethren, I understand by ὁμοούσιον God of God, not of an essence that is unlike, not divided but born, and that the Son has a birth which is unique, of the substance of the unborn God, that He is begotten yet co-eternal and wholly like the Father.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:739
verses.text: I believed this before I knew the word ὁμοούσιον but it greatly helped my belief.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:740
verses.text: Why do you condemn my faith when I express it by ὁμοούσιον while you cannot disapprove it when expressed by ὁμοιούσιον? For you condemn my faith, or rather your own, when you condemn its verbal equivalent.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:741
verses.text: Do others misunderstand it? Let us join in condemning the misunderstanding, but not deprive our faith of its security.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:742
verses.text: Do you think we must subscribe to the Samosatene Council to prevent any one from using ὁμοούσιον in the sense of Paul of Samosata? Then let us also subscribe to the Council of Nicaea, so that the Arians may not impugn the word.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:743
verses.text: Have we to fear that ὁμοιούσιον does not imply the same belief as ὁμοούσιον? Let us decree that there is no difference between being of one or of a similar substance.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:744
verses.text: The word ὁμοούσιον can be understood in a wrong sense.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:745
verses.text: Let us prove that it can be understood in a very good sense.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:746
verses.text: We hold one and the same sacred truth.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:747
verses.text: I beseech you that we should agree that this truth, which is one and the same, should be regarded as sacred.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:748
verses.text: Forgive me, brethren, as I have so often asked you to do.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:749
verses.text: You are not Arians: why should you be thought to be Arians by denying the ὁμοούσιον?  89.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:750
verses.text: But you say: 'The ambiguity of the word ὁμοούσιον troubles and offends me.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:751
verses.text: ' I pray you hear me again and be not offended.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:752
verses.text: I am troubled by the inadequacy of the word ὁμοιούσιον.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:753
verses.text: Many deceptions come from similarity.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:754
verses.text: I distrust vessels plated with gold, for I may be deceived by the metal underneath: and yet that which is seen resembles gold.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:755
verses.text: I distrust anything that looks like milk, lest that which is offered to me be milk but not sheep's milk: for cow's milk certainly looks like it.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:756
verses.text: Sheep's milk cannot be really like sheep's milk unless drawn from a sheep.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:757
verses.text: True likeness belongs to a true natural connection.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:758
verses.text: But when the true natural connection exists, the ὁμοούσιον is implied.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:759
verses.text: It is a likeness according to essence when one piece of metal is like another and not plated, if milk which is of the same colour as other milk is not different in taste.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:760
verses.text: Nothing can be like gold but gold, or like milk that did not belong to that species.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:761
verses.text: I have often been deceived by the colour of wine: and yet by tasting the liquor have recognized that it was of another kind.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:762
verses.text: I have seen meat look like other meat, but afterwards the flavour has revealed the difference to me.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:763
verses.text: Yes, I fear those resemblances which are not due to a unity of nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:764
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:765
verses.text: I am afraid, brethren, of the brood of heresies which are successively produced in the East: and I have already read what I tell you I fear.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:766
verses.text: There was nothing whatever suspicious in the document which some of you, with the assent of certain Orientals, took on your embassy to Sirmium to be there subscribed.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:767
verses.text: But some misunderstanding has arisen in reference to certain statements at the beginning which I believe you, my holy brethren, Basil, Eustathius, and Eleusius, omitted to mention lest they should give offence.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:768
verses.text: If it was right to draw them up, it was wrong to bury them in silence.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:769
verses.text: But if they are now unmentioned because they were wrong we must beware lest they should be repeated at some future time.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:770
verses.text: Out of consideration for you I have hitherto said nothing about this: yet you know as well as I do that this creed was not identical with the creed of Ancyra.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:771
verses.text: I am not talking gossip: I possess a copy of the creed, and I did not get it from laymen, it was given me by bishops.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:772
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:773
verses.text: I pray you, brethren, remove all suspicion and leave no occasion for it.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:774
verses.text: To approve of ὁμοιούσιον, we need not disapprove of ὁμοούσιον.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:775
verses.text: Let us think of the many holy prelates now at rest: what judgment will the Lord pronounce upon us if we now say anathema to them? What will be our case if we push the matter so far as to deny that they were bishops and so deny that we are ourselves bishops? We were ordained by them and are their successors.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:776
verses.text: Let us renounce our episcopate, if we took its office from men under anathema.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:777
verses.text: Brethren, forgive my anguish: it is an impious act that you are attempting.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:778
verses.text: I cannot endure to hear the man anathematized who says ὁμοούσιον and says it in the right sense.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:779
verses.text: No fault can be found with a word which does no harm to the meaning of religion.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:780
verses.text: I do not know the word ὁμοιούσιον, or understand it, unless it confesses a similarity of essence.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:781
verses.text: I call the God of heaven and earth to witness, that when I had heard neither word, my belief was always such that I should have interpreted ὁμοιούσιον by ὁμοούσιον.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:782
verses.text: That is, I believed that nothing could be similar according to nature unless it was of the same nature.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:783
verses.text: Though long ago regenerate in baptism, and for some time a bishop, I never heard of the Nicene creed until I was going into exile, but the Gospels and Epistles suggested to me the meaning of ὁμοούσιον and ὁμοιούσιον.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:784
verses.text: Our desire is sacred.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:785
verses.text: Let us not condemn the fathers, let us not encourage heretics, lest while we drive one heresy away, we nurture another.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:786
verses.text: After the Council of Nicaea our fathers interpreted the due meaning of ὁμοούσιον with scrupulous care; the books are extant, the facts are fresh in men's minds: if anything has to be added to the interpretation, let us consult together.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:787
verses.text: Between us we can thoroughly establish the faith, so that what has been well settled need not be disturbed, and what has been misunderstood may be removed.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:788
Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:789
verses.text: Beloved brethren, I have passed beyond the bounds of courtesy, and forgetting my modesty I have been compelled by my affection for you to write thus of many abstruse matters which until this our age were unattempted and left in silence.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:790
verses.text: I have spoken what I myself believed, conscious that I owed it as my soldier's service to the Church to send to you in accordance with the teaching of the Gospel by these letters the voice of the office which I hold in Christ.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:791
verses.text: It is yours to discuss, to provide and to act, that the inviolable fidelity in which you stand you may still keep with conscientious hearts, and that you may continue to hold what you hold now.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:792
verses.text: Remember my exile in your holy prayers.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:793
verses.text: I do not know, now that I have thus expounded the faith, whether it would be as sweet to return unto you again in the Lord Jesus Christ as it would be full of peace to die.

verses.name: Hilary of Poitiers: On the Councils or the Fiaht of the Easterns 1:794
verses.text: That our God and Lord may keep you pure and undefiled unto the day of His appearing is my desire, dearest brethren.
